It was an experiment in making a small, mobile abode before the tiny home trend took off. It offered a place to sleep, and dream. It was also in many ways an artwork.

headline: Jamila Woods’s Songs Have Many Loves
abstract: “Water Made Us,” a new album due Oct. 13, achieves the musician’s greatest synthesis yet between her voices as a poet and as a songwriter.
lead_paragraph: For many artists, the weeks leading up to a new album are a hectic flurry of promotional obligations, relentless tour rehearsals and omnipresent anxiety. But two months before the Oct. 13 release of Jamila Woods’s “Water Made Us,” the Chicago-based writer and musician was far from the music industry’s antic churn: at a six-week writing residency at a remote castle in Umbria, Italy.

headline: Putting Women at the Center of Human Evolution
abstract: Cat Bohannon’s book, “Eve,” looks at the way women’s bodies evolved, and how a focus on male subjects in science has left women “under-studied and under-cared for.”
lead_paragraph: The author Cat Bohannon was a preteen in Atlanta in the 1980s when she saw the film “2001: A Space Odyssey” for the first time. As she took in its famous opening scene, in which a bunch of apes picks up a bunch of bones and quickly begins using them to hit each other, Bohannon was struck by the sheer maleness of the moment.

headline: Google Goes on Trial Over Justice Dept. Claims That It Has Monopoly Power
abstract: The government claims that Google illegally stifles rivals, while the company says its practices are legal and mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial

headline: Fiber Art Is Finally Being Taken Seriously
abstract: Long caught in the liminal space between craft and something more prestigious, works of thread and fabric are reaching newfound institutional recognition.
lead_paragraph: IN FEBRUARY OF 1969, by a first-floor window that looked out on 53rd Street, the Museum of Modern Art in New York installed a work by a then-34-year-old artist named Sheila Hicks called “The Evolving Tapestry: He/She” (1967-68). Made of more than 3,000 “ponytails” of linen thread, as the artist called them, stitched together and piled atop one another, it looked at first glance like something one might encounter in a commercial fabric store. Neither traditional sculpture nor painting, it conjured both, a monumental object made from the humblest materials.

headline: 100 Easy Dinner Recipes for Right Now
abstract: September is overwhelming. These quick, weeknight-friendly dishes aren’t.
lead_paragraph: Oh, September. You are madness. You are back-to-school and back-to-work after August laze and Labor Day. You are crisp new notebooks and backpacks. You are closed-toe shoes. You are calendars cross-referenced, car pools arranged, nut-free lunches assembled.

headline: In ‘The Other Black Girl,’ the Call Is Coming From Inside the Cubicle
abstract: This satirical workplace thriller tracks the plight of an assistant as she endures terrors both mysterious and banal.
lead_paragraph: The loneliness, anxiety and discomfort that often comes with being the only Black person in a predominantly white space can turn any office into a mental and emotional minefield. But what if finally gaining a new Black co-worker only made matters worse?

headline: ‘Wounds Will Need to Be Healed’: Collisions in a Fractured Israel
abstract: Israelis are deeply split about what kind of country Israel should be. Four encounters at four recent protests show how that division plays out in daily life.
lead_paragraph: When Ana Lavi neared the gates of her village in southern Israel late one night in July, a small group of men appeared in the road, surrounded her car and blocked its path.

headline: Global Health’s Dirty Secret: Rich Countries Get Good Medicine, and the Poor Sometimes Get Poison
abstract: A chaotic system for regulating drugs leaves the world exposed to the next pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In April a pregnant woman died at a hospital in Kandy, Sri Lanka, of complications blamed on an anesthetic manufactured in India. A few months earlier, Indian-made cough syrups were linked to the deaths of children in Gambia and Uzbekistan. Substandard medicines also were found this year in the Marshall Islands and Micronesia before they could do any harm.

headline: How the Underground Railroad Got Its Name
abstract: The Underground Railroad got its name from the most fascinating and important African American activist and writer you’ve never heard of.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Smallwood was a busy man in the summer of 1842. Born into slavery outside Washington, D.C., in 1801, he had largely educated himself and bought his own freedom 11 years before. By day, he ran a shoemaking business from the little house he shared with his wife and four children a short walk from the U.S. Capitol. By night, he was organizing daring, dangerous escapes from slavery — not by ones and twos but by the wagonload — from Washington, Baltimore and the surrounding counties.

headline: Who’s Who in the Google Monopoly Trial
abstract: The federal government’s first monopoly trial this century will feature top tech executives, experienced litigators and an Obama-appointed judge.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from Google’s antitrust trial

headline: Her Choice: Love, or the Lease on a Beloved Studio. It Took Some Thought.
abstract: Taking guidance from a favorite childhood novel, “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,” a woman says she had to decide what kind of a person she wanted to be.

headline: The Big City Where Housing Is Still Affordable
abstract: Tokyo has succeeded in maintaining an abundance of affordable housing because it has no downtown, many railroads and laws that make it easy to build.
lead_paragraph: Yuta Yamasaki and his wife moved from southern Japan to Tokyo a decade ago because job prospects were better in the big city. They now have three sons — ages 10, 8 and 6 — and they are looking for a larger place to live. But Mr. Yamasaki, who runs a gelato shop, and his wife, a child-care worker, aren’t planning to move far. They are confident they can find an affordable three-bedroom apartment in their own neighborhood.

headline: Theaters of War That Make Up the Fighting in Ukraine
abstract: A “striking fist” in the North, and river crossings in the South. Along a jagged 1,000-mile front, the fighting is multifaceted — and relentless.
lead_paragraph: Along the southern reaches of the Dnipro River, Ukrainian forces are staging amphibious assaults on Russian positions across the river from around the city of Kherson, forcing Russia to deploy already-stretched units to prevent Ukraine from gaining a foothold on the eastern bank.

headline: In J.M. Coetzee’s New Novel, Love Awakens an Austere Soul
abstract: “The Pole” explores romance, mortality and the tangled ways we communicate.
lead_paragraph: The South African writer J.M. Coetzee’s novels are slim, and so, by and large, are his characters — they’re Modiglianis, not Boteros. The most wraithlike, a saintly hunger artist, is the protagonist of his novel “The Life and Times of Michael K,” which won the Booker Prize in 1983.

headline: Microsoft, Google and Antitrust: Similar Legal Theories in a Different Era
abstract: The government’s antitrust case against Google borrows heavily from the landmark lawsuit against Microsoft 25 years ago. But it lacks the same cultural impact.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department argues in a federal antitrust suit that Google is a dominant tech company that has abused its market power to bully industry partners, protect its monopoly and thwart competition.

headline: As Ukraine Aid Benefits Their Districts, Some House Republicans Oppose It
abstract: The American push to fund Kyiv’s war effort has created big economic opportunities for Mesquite, Texas, and other cities around the country. Some of their G.O.P. congressmen want to end it.
lead_paragraph: By early next year, this city best known for being the rodeo capital of Texas is on track to become a centerpiece of the American effort to increase artillery production vital to the war in Ukraine.

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Gregory Ain-designed house in Altadena, a mountain retreat in Tahoma and a midcentury-modern escape in Palm Springs.
lead_paragraph: This is one of 28 houses in the Park Planned Homes development, an early midcentury-modern tract of homes near the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains. Gregory Ain, the architect, and Garrett Eckbo, the landscape architect, created a plan that promoted visual continuity by eliminating fences in front of the homes and using glass walls to divide interior spaces from the courtyards outside.

headline: 50 Years Ago, a Bloody Coup Ended Democracy in Chile
abstract: Gen. Augusto Pinochet led the violent overthrow of the socialist government of Salvador Allende, seizing power for nearly 17 years. Here is a selection of photographs from the coup and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago on Monday, a violent coup ended one of Latin America’s most stable democracies, brought an abrupt halt to the Chilean military’s tradition of noninvolvement in politics and ushered in 17 years of ruthless dictatorship.

headline: As Smartphone Industry Sputters, the iPhone Expands Its Dominance
abstract: Apple, which is set to release a new iPhone on Tuesday, has increased its share of smartphone sales by converting Android customers and adding teenagers.
lead_paragraph: There’s a general rule about consumer electronics: The older a device becomes, the more competitors appear and prices fall. This was true for televisions, personal computers and portable music players.

headline: We Need Shopping Malls, or Something Like Them
abstract: Despite my deep conviction that conspicuous consumption is one of the many reasons our planet is in terrible trouble, I have come to love the mall.
lead_paragraph: It was already hot at 5:45 in the morning, the humidity so thick it left me breathless. Even for the South, this was extreme: frog-strangling humidity, smother-you-in-your-sleep heat. It blanketed the region, day after day after day. At one point the forecast called for a heat index here in Nashville that was higher than the heat index in Las Vegas. If you spend much time outdoors in heat like that, it might kill you.

headline: Why Is the Biden Administration Working So Hard on a Saudi-Israel Deal?
abstract: Washington is pushing for ties between the two countries, with a promise of security guarantees for Riyadh.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is working overtime to consolidate what is arguably Washington’s most significant advantage over its great power rivals, especially China. That advantage lies in the Middle East.

headline: Explore How Income Influences Attendance at 139 Top Colleges
abstract: Unlike many elite colleges, most flagship public colleges are “pretty fair in who gets in.”
lead_paragraph: Unlike many elite colleges, most flagship public colleges are “pretty fair in who gets in.”

headline: When Does a Style Become a Classic?
abstract: In a sea of trends, a reader wonders how to identify a timeless clothing item.
lead_paragraph: “Classic” is one of those words everyone throws around but almost no one defines. Most people’s attitudes toward identifying classics seem to mirror Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart’s, well, classic, words about pornography in Jacobellis v. Ohio: “I know it when I see it.”

headline: Elon Musk Has Crossed a Line
abstract: A consistent booster of far-right and antisemitic accounts on Twitter, Elon Musk is now melding a sense of victimhood with the most toxic elements of the right.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, one of the world’s richest men who is now most famous for running the website X, formerly known as Twitter, has a new excuse for the company’s shaky performance since he bought it last year. The problem, according to Mr. Musk, is the Jews.

headline: F.D.A. Approves New Covid Shots
abstract: A nationwide rollout of the vaccines by Pfizer and Moderna should begin later this week, after the C.D.C. considers guidelines to prepare Americans for this season when infections usually tick upward.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new round of Covid boosters on Monday, that will arrive alongside the seasonal flu vaccine and shots to protect infants and older adults from R.S.V., a potentially lethal respiratory virus.

headline: Trump’s Electoral College Edge Seems to Be Fading
abstract: Democrats appear resilient in the battleground states despite a nationwide loss of nonwhite support. New issues may be one reason.
lead_paragraph: The early polls show Donald J. Trump and President Biden tied nationwide. Does that mean Mr. Trump has a clear advantage in the battleground states that decide the Electoral College?

headline: Trump Is Really Old, Too
abstract: Why is Joe Biden’s age a bigger issue than the former president’s?
lead_paragraph: To our intensifying discussion about whether President Biden has grown mentally fuzzy and too old for a second term, I’d like to add this question: How would we even notice Donald Trump’s lapse into incoherence, when derangement is essentially his brand?

headline: Chinese Warnings on iPhones Tap Deep Strain of Security Concerns
abstract: For years, officials in China have been told to shun foreign devices. Now reports of renewed curbs have unnerved Apple’s investors, heightening geopolitical tensions.
lead_paragraph: China has discouraged the use of foreign-made electronic devices by government officials for a decade. It has told agencies and state-owned companies to replace American computer servers and other devices with domestic ones. And officials frequently show off to Americans their phones made by Huawei, China’s cellphone giant.

headline: Once Again You Lose Me at the Wall
abstract: The wall isn’t very useful at stopping migrants, but it’s great as a symbol of our worst impulses.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Democratic mayors and governors are warning the Biden administration that the migrants crossing our southern border are straining their cities and states to the breaking point. New York City alone is sheltering and feeding an average of 59,000 migrants a day. What’s your advice to the White House?

headline: Today’s Top News: The Aftermath of the Earthquake in Morocco, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: U.S. v. Google
abstract: The government has set its sights on the internet behemoth in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.
lead_paragraph: For years, the government has been trying to rein in Big Tech, pursuing some of the largest and most powerful companies on the internet. This week, the government takes on Google in the first monopoly trial of the modern internet era.

headline: Treating Overdoses Over the Counter
abstract: It is now easier than ever to get a medication that stops overdoses.
lead_paragraph: America’s overdose crisis has prompted a significant shift in the war on drugs. Just last week, Narcan, a medication that stops opioid overdoses, became available nationwide without a prescription for the first time.

headline: Investors Warily Await the Instacart and Arm I.P.O.s
abstract: The valuations for both companies have come in below expectations, reflecting a cautious outlook on Wall Street as firms start to go public again after a fallow patch.
lead_paragraph: Instacart just published the latest prospectus for its initial public offering, with the grocery delivery company aiming for a valuation of up to $9.3 billion when it prices its shares as soon as next week.

headline: The Moroccan government defends its quake response, but the king is little in evidence.
abstract: King Mohammed VI waited hours before making his first public statement on the disaster, and has made few since. It was a government spokesman who pushed back on Monday against growing criticism on the pace of rescue efforts.
lead_paragraph: As public criticism mounted over the pace and efficiency of Morocco’s earthquake response, King Mohammed VI’s government issued its first public defense of the operation on Monday, saying the authorities had promptly addressed the disaster and were dedicating their efforts to rescue operations.

headline: For Biden, Who Neither Fought in Vietnam Nor Protested War, Trip Offered Opportunity
abstract: While others of his generation were scarred by the conflict, President Biden forged a strategic partnership on his first visit to the country, framing it in pragmatic terms.
lead_paragraph: As he wrapped up a two-day trip to Hanoi, his first visit to Vietnam, President Biden on Monday made a point of stopping by a memorial to his old friend, Senator John McCain, the famed prisoner of war who was later instrumental in forging reconciliation with a onetime enemy.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Sept. 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: Joey Votto Is Finally Ready to Meet You
abstract: In the 17th season of a Hall of Fame-worthy career, Votto has made the unusual shift from meticulous hitting savant to social media star.
lead_paragraph: On a July night in Milwaukee, Joey Votto got his revenge.

headline: Getting to Genius, Part 2: Becoming Queen Bee
abstract: How to use the game’s tools and the “Hivemind” to your advantage.
lead_paragraph: This is Part 2 of a two-part series on learning to solve Spelling Bee. Be sure to check out Part 1.

headline: Getting to Genius, Part 1: Spelling Bee for Beginners
abstract: Two Games editors take you through the best ways to move up the ranks.
lead_paragraph: This is Part 1 of a two-part series on learning to solve Spelling Bee. Be sure to check out Part 2.

headline: Inside Los Angeles’s Fraught Redistricting Process
abstract: A conversation with Jill Cowan, who spent months reporting on how members of the City Council redrew political maps to largely maintain their power.
lead_paragraph: You may remember the explosive recording of Los Angeles City Council members that was leaked last year. The profanity-laced audio, in which L.A. leaders can be heard mocking people in racist terms, stunned the city and prompted several high-profile resignations.

headline: A Horrible Loss for the Giants, but Not the Worst Ever
abstract: The Giants were embarrassed at home by the Dallas Cowboys in a 40-0 laugher that was among the worst season openers in N.F.L. history. But all hope is not lost.
lead_paragraph: The Giants got the kickoff at home on Sunday night and advanced to the Dallas Cowboys’ 8-yard line in nine plays. What a start to the season!

headline: Red Cross Blames Climate Disasters for Blood Shortage
abstract: The supply in the United States has fallen nearly 25 percent since early August, the organization said.
lead_paragraph: The blood supply in the United States has dropped to critically low levels, in part because of “back-to-back months of worsening climate-related disasters,” the American Red Cross said on Monday.

headline: Jimmy Buffett’s Hits Album Reaches the Top 10 After His Death
abstract: The new LP by the singer-songwriter Zach Bryan holds at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, after a ticket sale for his new tour and the musician’s arrest in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Zach Bryan repeats at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, while a nearly 40-year-old compilation by Jimmy Buffett rockets into the Top 10 following his death on Sept. 1, at 76.

headline: Some Things Are More Important Than History
abstract: As a no-hitter stretched into extra innings, a journalist rooted for something extraordinary while his son just wanted the Yankees to win. They both got what they wanted.
lead_paragraph: He didn’t care that it was a no-hitter. He just wanted the Yankees to win.

headline: BMW Says It Will Invest $750 Million to Build Electric Minis in Oxford
abstract: The move is a boost for Britain’s car industry, but uncertainty remains about the sector’s future in the country.
lead_paragraph: BMW said on Monday that it would invest 600 million pounds, or about $750 million, to build electric versions of its popular Mini car models in Britain.

headline: Do You Know These Recent Screen Adaptations of Popular Y.A. Novels?
abstract: Fantasy, romance and adventure novels written for young adults have long been the basis for movies and television shows. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy, romance and adventure novels written for young adults have long been the basis for movies and television shows. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.

headline: Somber 9/11 Ceremony Draws Mourners to Ground Zero
abstract: Relatives of those who died went to Lower Manhattan to mark the 22nd anniversary of the terrorist attack, where they were joined by governors, senators and the vice president.
lead_paragraph: Mourners gathered in grief in Lower Manhattan on Monday, hugging each other and fighting back tears as they commemorated their lost loved ones on the 22nd anniversary of Sept. 11.

headline: A Diver Feared the Titan Sub, but Couldn’t Resist the Titanic
abstract: Paul-Henri Nargeolet mixed decades of passion for the ship of dreams with repeated dives and recoveries meant to save what remained of the famous ocean liner.
lead_paragraph: A riddle haunts the Titan disaster. It’s the presence on the doomed craft of Paul-Henri Nargeolet, 77. The Frenchman was one of the world’s great submariners. So why was he, of all people, diving repeatedly to the Titanic on a submersible that many experts saw as a catastrophe waiting to happen?

headline: This One-Pot Orzo With Bacon Uses a Clever Corn Trick
abstract: Don’t slice your kernels. Grate them instead for this creamy, extra-corny dinner that’s ready in less than an hour.
lead_paragraph: I thought I’d tried every way there was to cut the kernels off an ear of corn. I braced the ears in a Bundt pan and sunk them into a deep bowl; I held them horizontally and I held them vertically. I even tested out some of those single-task corn-slicing tools, none of which did any better than a cutting board and a knife. But until I saw Samantha Seneviratne’s new recipe for creamy one-pot orzo with corn and bacon, it had never occurred to me to pull out the box grater.

headline: The Tissue That Connects Our Muscles May Be a Key to Better Health
abstract: Fascia is more important than previously thought. Here’s how, and why, you should care for yours.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the concept of caring for one’s fascia — the tough, flexible tissue that surrounds and connects muscles, bones and organs like cling wrap — has permeated fitness and wellness culture. Pilates instructors and massage therapists offer to make fascia more supple, and products like foam rollers, massage guns and “fascia blasters” claim to help you improve your fascia health at home.

headline: Is School Choice Destroying Public Education?
abstract: In a new book, Cara Fitzpatrick traces the rise of the movement to expand public funding for privately operated institutions.
lead_paragraph: Cara Fitzpatrick’s first book,“The Death of Public School,” opens with a superb survey of the political, cultural, legal and natural forces undermining public trust in our nation’s schools. The terrible disruption of the pandemic. The Republican-fueled culture wars over gender and race in the curriculum. The decades-long conservative campaign to legalize private school vouchers, capped by last year’s Supreme Court ruling that parents must be allowed to spend those vouchers at religious as well as secular schools.

headline: As Covid-19 Cases Tick Higher, Conspiracy Theorists Stoke New Fears
abstract: A late-summer rise in Covid-19 infections is bringing with it a wave of conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: As Covid-19 cases have climbed as part of a late-summer uptick, right-wing influencers and conspiracy theorists have responded by stoking fears about mass lockdowns and spreading unsubstantiated new ideas about Covid-19’s links to world events.

headline: Ian Wilmut, Scientist Behind Dolly the Cloned Sheep, Is Dead at 79
abstract: He led a project in Scotland that, in 1996, cloned a mammal for the first time, a feat of genetic engineering that shocked the world.
lead_paragraph: Ian Wilmut, the British scientist who led the project that cloned a mammal for the first time, Dolly the sheep, shocking scientists who had thought that such a procedure was impossible, died on Sunday. He was 79.

headline: ‘Special Ops: Lioness’ Reconsidered
abstract: Taylor Sheridan’s latest series for Paramount+ deserved a longer look.
lead_paragraph: Contains spoilers for the recently concluded first season of “Special Ops: Lioness.”

headline: Israelis Have Been Protesting for Months. Now, Americans Are Joining Them.
abstract: American Jews have been reluctant to join in demonstrations against Israel’s plans to overhaul its judiciary, but some are overcoming their resistance.
lead_paragraph: For months, Beth Levine, an attorney in New York, grew worried about developments in Israel, where the far-right government has sought to diminish the judicial branch’s independence. Its efforts provoked massive protests in Israel and smaller ones in the United States, including most Sundays in Manhattan’s Washington Square Park. Though sympathetic to the cause, Ms. Levine, who lives in the Bronx, never attended.

headline: Review: Boris Charmatz Unveils a Different Tanztheater Wuppertal
abstract: Charmatz’s first new work for the company founded by Pina Bausch was a messy, meandering grab-bag of ideas and inspirations.
lead_paragraph: Everyone needs an editor. Writers, directors, cooks, choreographers and designers all need a ruthless eye — internal or external — for their work to find its form; the sculpture within the block of stone. You might even define a great artist by the ability to pitilessly remove the inessential, no matter how clever the sentence or brilliant the movement composition.

headline: Disney and Charter Reach Agreement, Ending Cable Standoff
abstract: The impasse between the two companies had raised questions about the future of the cable bundle.
lead_paragraph: Disney and Charter said Monday that they had reached a deal to resolve their programming dispute, ending a skirmish that raised questions about the future of cable television.

headline: Rachel McAdams to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Mary Jane’
abstract: The play, by Amy Herzog, is about a mother caring for a chronically ill child.
lead_paragraph: The film star Rachel McAdams will make her Broadway debut next spring in an acclaimed and heart-wrenching play about a mother caring for a small child with a serious illness.

headline: When New York Was ‘Drop Dead City’
abstract: A documentary about the city’s fiscal crisis of the 1970s, co-directed by the son of one of its saviors, wins the Library of Congress Lavine/Ken Burns Prize for Film.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 29, 1975, Mike O’Neill, the editor of The Daily News, and Bill Brink, the managing editor, returned from lunch and asked whether President Gerald R. Ford, while addressing the National Press Club in Washington, had agreed to help New York City avoid bankruptcy.

headline: The Met Commissions an Opera About Abducted Ukrainian Children
abstract: The work, by the Ukrainian composer Maxim Kolomiiets and the American playwright George Brant, is inspired by the accounts of mothers whose children were taken during the war.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera announced Monday that it had commissioned a new opera about Russia’s abduction and deportation of thousands of Ukrainian children, the latest action by the company to show support for war-torn Ukraine.

headline: A New N.B.A. Champion’s Takeaway From a U.F.C. Champ: Relax
abstract: Denver Nuggets guard Jamal Murray’s friendship with Alexander Volkanovski, the U.F.C. featherweight champion, is changing his approach to winning.
lead_paragraph: It was a Sunday afternoon in early July, and Jamal Murray had been in Las Vegas for a few days — enough time for the city to wear out anyone.

headline: Ukraine Claims to Have Retaken Oil and Gas Platforms in the Black Sea
abstract: The platforms have played a role in Russia’s ability to project power off Ukraine’s coast since Moscow seized them in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said on Monday that it had taken control of several oil and gas platforms in the Black Sea, after a series of clashes with Russian aerial and maritime forces in the waters between Odesa and the occupied Crimean Peninsula.

headline: Mayor Adams and the Migrant Crisis in New York
abstract: Responses to Mayor Eric Adams’s remarks about the migrant influx. Also: President Biden’s silence on the Trump indictments; football; pornography; plastics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mimi Leder Believes in Big Feelings
abstract: In an interview, the veteran director discussed her career and her work on “The Morning Show,” returning Wednesday for its third season on Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Leder wasn’t born with a camera in her hand. But it didn’t take her long to pick one up. Her father was Paul Leder, an auteur of, in her words, “ultra ultra low-budget films.” She and her two siblings worked on them — shooting, writing, editing, more.

headline: ‘Virginia Is the Test Case’: Youngkin Pushes for G.O.P. Takeover This Fall
abstract: Glenn Youngkin, a popular Republican governor with national ambitions, is trying to help his party take full control of state government in crucial legislative races this year.
lead_paragraph: Virginia, whose off-year elections are usually closely watched as an indicator of the national mood, has been mostly out of the spotlight this year, overshadowed by the Republican presidential primary and the looming general election clash.

headline: Alfredo Martinez, Who Fused Art World and Underworld, Dies at 56
abstract: He created hoopla around art made in prison — first in the early 2000s, with himself as the artist, then 20 years later with the scammer Anna Sorokin.
lead_paragraph: Alfredo Martinez lived on New York City’s margins, a squatter who shook off one eviction after another. He was an artist who usually lacked a gallery and sometimes  put on exhibits in a storage locker.

headline: Twinkies and Jam to Mix as Smucker Buys Hostess for $5.6 Billion
abstract: J.M. Smucker, the maker of jellies, Jif peanut butter and Uncrustables, agreed to take over Hostess Brands, adding Twinkies, Ho Hos and Ding Dongs to its portfolio of snacks.
lead_paragraph: In a sugary union of major snack makers, J.M. Smucker, known for its jellies, Jif peanut butter and many other brands, agreed to acquire Hostess Brands, the maker of Twinkies, Ho Hos and Ding Dongs, in a deal worth $5.6 billion.

headline: Fashion Tribes of New York
abstract: Ralph Lauren, Coach, Proenza Schouler and Khaite: Recognize your camouflage?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since New York was the main character in any costume drama, a while since it starred as anything other than a problem: abandoned, messy, crime-ridden, economically challenged. But as New York Fashion Week began, the city’s designers were telling a different story. One about the city as a place of chaos, movement and dreams.

headline: Robert S. Bennett, Washington’s Go-to Lawyer in a Scandal, Dies at 84
abstract: He was a robust defender of a host of high-profile clients, including Bill Clinton over the president’s relationship with an intern.
lead_paragraph: Robert S. Bennett, one of the nation’s leading criminal defense lawyers, who was known for his representation of the powerful and celebrated caught up in scandals, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

headline: Cuomo Wins Book Lawsuit, Leaving New York’s Ethics Panel in Limbo
abstract: A state judge sided with former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s argument that a new state ethics commission was created in a way that violated the State Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s legal fight to preserve the proceeds of a $5.1 million book deal took a stunning turn on Monday when a state judge essentially invalidated New York’s new ethics commission, which was investigating the book deal.

headline: Rubiales Quits, but Women’s Soccer in Spain Is Still Troubled
abstract: After the resignation of the country’s soccer chief, recriminations, accusations and an inquiry remain.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of protests and calls for his resignation, Spain’s soccer chief, Luis Rubiales, has quit, but the problems that surfaced in the wake of his forcible kiss of a player after the Women’s World Cup remain.

headline: Escapee Had Been a Fugitive Before Pennsylvania Jailbreak
abstract: The subject of the manhunt outside Philadelphia disappeared into the wilderness in 2017 after an arrest warrant was issued in connection with a murder in northern Brazil.
lead_paragraph: It was just after midnight on a Saturday. A light rain was starting to fall in the mostly empty town square by the church.

headline: 13 Years Later, Construction to Restart on Hudson River Rail Tunnel
abstract: As soon as next month, work could begin on the first steps to create a two-track tunnel at the center of the Gateway project.
lead_paragraph: After a 13-year detour, work is about to begin again in New Jersey on a rail tunnel that would run all the way to Midtown Manhattan and end the region’s reliance on a pair of crumbling tubes built more than a century ago.

headline: Hundreds Reported Dead in Severe Libya Flooding
abstract: The waters swept away hundreds of homes as emergency officials raced to find survivors of the flooding caused by torrential weekend rains. Officials in one city described “catastrophic” devastation.
lead_paragraph: Deadly floods swept through northeastern Libya over the weekend, with the top official in the region warning that the toll could exceed 2,000 dead as rescue teams searched for survivors.

headline: Governor Youngkin Pardons Father Who Was Arrested in School Board Meeting
abstract: In a Loudoun County, Va., case that became a national flashpoint over transgender rights, Scott Smith rose to accuse a boy of assaulting his daughter, and a fight ensued.
lead_paragraph: In a case that became a national flashpoint over transgender rights in schools, Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia has pardoned a father who was arrested during a contentious school board meeting in Loudoun County.

headline: Rescuers From Spain Search for Survivors in Morocco
abstract: Spanish rescue teams aided Moroccan crews in searching for victims of the powerful earthquake that devastated the country.
lead_paragraph: Spanish rescue teams aided Moroccan crews in searching for victims of the powerful earthquake that devastated the country.

headline: Manhattan Judge May Be Open to Moving Trump Trial Date as Cases Mount
abstract: The judge, Juan M. Merchan, said in a letter that while he was not yet ready to discuss potential changes to the March 25, 2024, trial date, he would be willing to have the conversation in February.
lead_paragraph: The judge presiding over the criminal case against Donald J. Trump in Manhattan signaled that he could be open to changing the date of the trial — now set for March 2024 — in light of the handful of other potential trials the former president now faces.

headline: Kim Jong-un Has Something Putin Needs, and That’s a New Wrinkle
abstract: Kim Jong-un has ammunition stocks that Russia covets as it continues its war in Ukraine, and North Korea may get advanced technology and badly needed food aid in return.
lead_paragraph: When North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, visited President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia four years ago, it was mostly for diplomatic show.

headline: The Unfinished Pursuit of a Better Poverty Measure
abstract: The official poverty measure is widely disliked, but experts may never agree on how to perfect it.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the Census Bureau is scheduled to release income and poverty statistics for 2022. It’s safe to say that the report will be hard to interpret. Last year, the two poverty measures released by the bureau pointed in opposite directions. One showed that poverty increased slightly in 2021, while the other showed it declined markedly.

headline: Aid Trickles In to Moroccans Stranded by Quake, but Desperation Mounts
abstract: The government defended its response to the earthquake as robust, but some residents desperate for basic supplies say they feel abandoned.
lead_paragraph: Government rescue workers began to reach some devastated mountain villages in Morocco on Monday, but many more settlements were waiting desperately for help, three days after the country was hit by the strongest earthquake in the area in more than a century.

headline: Drew Barrymore’s Show Is Picketed as It Resumes Amid Writers’ Strike
abstract: The star, who dropped out of an MTV awards show in May to demonstrate solidarity with striking writers, plans to bring her daytime talk show back without its unionized writers.
lead_paragraph: When Drew Barrymore announced in May that she was stepping down as host of the MTV Movie & TV Awards to show solidarity with striking Hollywood writers, she received an outpouring of praise from fans and viewers who supported her stance.

headline: Federal Court Says Consumer Watchdog Can’t Check Banks for Discrimination
abstract: A Texas judge’s sweeping ruling says the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau exceeded its authority in trying to examine banks for uneven treatment.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas ruled that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is overstepping its bounds in its attempts to check whether banks and other financial firms are discriminating against Black Americans and other minorities.

headline: Feinstein Battle Over Her Late Husband’s Fortune Heads to Mediation
abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein, 90, and her daughter are locked in a dispute with her late husband’s family over how to manage the assets of his vast estate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Dianne Feinstein has died at 90. Read the latest updates here.

headline: 50 Years After a Plane Crash, Their Grief Still Resonates
abstract: In 1973, Delta Flight 723 went down in Boston, killing 89 people. Fifty years later, the family members left behind found solace in one another.
lead_paragraph: In February 2021, Ellen Barry, a Boston-based reporter who covers mental health for The New York Times, came across an article in Seven Days, a Vermont weekly newspaper, that piqued her interest. The piece focused on Michelle Brennen, who was 10 years old when her father died in a plane crash that had occurred nearly 50 years earlier. On a foggy day in 1973, Delta Flight 723 collided into a sea wall that separated Boston Harbor from Logan International Airport, killing all 89 people on board. Ms. Brennen, the article reported, was searching for family members of those who had died; she wanted to bring them together for a memorial.

headline: China Sows Disinformation About Hawaii Fires Using New Techniques
abstract: Beijing’s influence campaign using artificial intelligence is a rapid change in tactics, researchers from Microsoft and other organizations say.
lead_paragraph: When wildfires swept across Maui last month with destructive fury, China’s increasingly resourceful information warriors pounced.

headline: The Museum at FIT Explores the Intersection of Food and Fashion
abstract: Check out new vegetable varieties from Dan Barber’s Row 7, pick up a round braided challah for the holiday and more food news.
lead_paragraph: “Food & Fashion” — an exhibit at FIT’s museum that coincides with Fashion Week — begins with a gallery that shows food themes in fashion then moves into a space designed like a food hall with stalls that explore how food and dining have dictated fashion from the 18th century forward. There is also a display that illustrate the intersection of food and art in fashion, and how fashion depicts foods, like Issey Miyake’s accessories made to look like sushi and Judith Leiber’s tomato minaudière. Sweets and femininity, fashion and its relationship to issues like activism and sustainability, and how the fashionable body dictates food choices are also explored. The exhibit was organized by Melissa Marra-Alvarez, the museum’s curator of education and research, and Elizabeth Way, an associate curator of costume.

headline: Nelia Sancho, Beauty Queen Turned Defiant Rights Activist, Dies at 71
abstract: She had been competing in pageants in the Philippines, but she found her calling when she observed the offenses of the Marcos regime firsthand.
lead_paragraph: Nelia Sancho was a 22-year-old student at the University of the Philippines when she witnessed something no student should see: Two of her professors were shot point-blank by government agents in front of her. They had been considered enemies of the state by the despotic regime of President Ferdinand Marcos for their involvement in the Communist Party.

headline: Sanity Question and Plea Talks Shadow Coming Sept. 11 Hearings
abstract: Prosecutors issued a new deadline of next week on their offer to have the defendants plead guilty and avoid a capital trial.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have issued a new deadline — Sept. 18 — for four detainees at the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to show their willingness to plead guilty to plotting the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and receive a maximum punishment of life in prison.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Aid Trickles In to Morocco
abstract: Also, a Q&A with Elon Musk’s biographer.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll from the earthquake rose to at least 2,862 and many settlements waited desperately for help, a senior Moroccan official insisted that the authorities had promptly addressed the disaster amid public criticism over the pace of aid.

headline: Contractor for U.S. Government Charged With Spying for Ethiopia, Officials Say
abstract: The connection of the contractor to Ethiopia, a country that is a significant recipient of aid from the United States, is unusual.
lead_paragraph: A contractor who has worked for the State and Justice Departments has been arrested and charged with spying for Ethiopia, according to several U.S. officials with knowledge of the situation.

headline: What to Know About the New Covid Shots
abstract: The updated shots are now available in the U.S. Here’s who should get them and what to expect.
lead_paragraph: Two new Covid shots have received the green light from the Food and Drug Administration as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The vaccines, developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, are recommended for everyone 6 months and up and are available at pharmacies across the country.

headline: Fury as Quake Help Finally Arrives: ‘How Many Hours Has It Been?’
abstract: The people of a village high in the Atlas Mountains erupted in anger when the Moroccan government left them alone for three days to dig out and bury their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: When the earth seized his house and shook it late Friday night, Mohamed Abarada ran outside with his 9-month-old daughter in his arms. His mother, his wife and his 9-year-old daughter were still inside, trapped.

headline: Robin Roberts and Amber Laign Speak ‘Freely, Openly and Passionately’ About Their Love
abstract: The couple were wed Sept. 8 in an intimate ceremony at their home in Farmington, Conn. The newlyweds spoke to The New York Times in an exclusive interview about their relationship.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday morning, after ABC’s “Good Morning America” had finished its broadcast, Robin Rene Roberts and Amber Laign sat in the corner table of a restaurant a couple hundred feet away from the studio.

headline: A Party for Steven Meisel, Without Steven Meisel
abstract: The fashion world came out to honor the star photographer. He didn’t show.
lead_paragraph: At a cocktail party in Lower Manhattan on Friday to celebrate a new collection of clothing and accessories designed by the fashion photographer Steven Meisel for Zara, practically the only boldface name who didn’t show up was Steven Meisel.

headline: Trump Seeks Recusal of Judge in Federal Elections Case
abstract: The former president said Judge Tanya S. Chutkan, who is hearing the Justice Department’s case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election, had shown bias against him in public statements.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Monday asked the federal judge overseeing his looming trial on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election to recuse herself, claiming that she has shown a bias against Mr. Trump in public statements made from the bench in other cases.

headline: Videos of ‘Earthquake Lights’ Above Morocco Are an Unexplained Mystery.
abstract: Sightings of aerial luminous phenomena, often observed during earthquakes, are being shared online. Experts aren’t sure what causes them.
lead_paragraph: People near Marrakesh, Morocco, shared videos recorded before the 6.8-magnitude earthquake that hit the area last Friday, showing unidentified lights in the sky. The bizarre aerial phenomena are known as earthquake lights, and seem to occur above sites of seismic stress.

headline: As Democratic Jitters Grow, Biden Campaign Tries to Showcase His Vigor
abstract: With low approval ratings and shaky public performances, the president and his team are planning an ad blitz and trying to reassure voters about his age.
lead_paragraph: With stubbornly subterranean approval numbers, President Biden is taking early steps to shore up his re-election candidacy with a multipronged strategy that includes a costly advertising campaign and leveraging the powers of the bully pulpit.

headline: The F.D.A. Approved New Covid Shots
abstract: Also, a new biography of Elon Musk. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. gave the green light today to a new round of Covid boosters, the first to be approved since the public health emergency ended in May. The move comes as the Biden administration is preparing a campaign to convince Americans to get immunized, and as Covid cases tick up.

headline: U.K.’s Arrest of Suspected Spy Fuels Calls for Tougher Stance on China
abstract: Allegations that a researcher in Parliament was a foreign agent have intensified a fiery debate over Britain’s relations with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Even by the prolific standards of China’s foreign influence operations, it would represent a sensational case of infiltration.

headline: Sarah Burton Exits Alexander McQueen
abstract: The British designer and successor to Mr. McQueen will leave the label she has led for 13 years after one last show at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Burton, the fashion designer who took over the namesake label of Lee Alexander McQueen months after his death in 2010, and who created the gown worn by Princess Catherine at her wedding to Prince William a year later, is leaving the brand, its parent company, Kering, said in a statement released Monday.

headline: American Cave Expert Is Rescued in Turkey
abstract: Mark Dickey became sick deep underground more than a week ago. His safe extraction brought together cavers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: An American cave expert who became ill while he was more than 3,000 feet underground in a cave in Turkey, prompting an international rescue effort, was pulled safely from the cave soon after midnight Tuesday morning local time and immediately brought to a medical tent, the Speleological Federation of Turkey announced in a statement.

headline: Restaurants and Unions Agree to Raise Pay to $20 an Hour in California
abstract: The deal will avoid a ballot fight over a law passed last year that could have resulted in higher pay and other changes opposed by restaurant companies and franchisees.
lead_paragraph: Labor groups and fast-food companies in California have reached an agreement that will pave the way for workers in the industry to receive a minimum wage of $20 per hour.

headline: McCarthy Is Under the Gun as the House Returns for a Spending Fight
abstract: Speaker Kevin McCarthy faces his biggest test since the debt ceiling showdown as right-wing Republicans demand deep spending cuts and tougher border policies opposed by the White House and Senate.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s job is on the line as the House returns on Tuesday to confront a funding impasse that could lead to a government shutdown or a challenge to the California Republican’s hold on the top post in the House.

headline: Biden’s News Conference in Vietnam Ignites His Opponents
abstract: The president’s top aides believe that stories about the president’s age and health are stoked by his enemies in an effort to undermine his accomplishments.
lead_paragraph: In three days of diplomacy in Asia, President Biden rallied world leaders to help finance poor nations, fortified the coalition backing Ukraine and struck a deal with Vietnam to counter Chinese aggression.

headline: How Goldilocks Came to the U.S. Economy
abstract: The optimists were right. But why?
lead_paragraph: Early this year many economists held a very grim view about the prospects for reducing inflation without a major economic slowdown and a big rise in unemployment. One prominent economist declared that underlying inflation was at least 4.5 percent and that “all the hoped-for saviors” — that is, forces that might bring inflation down painlessly — “have come and gone.” Inflation, another declared, would be “sticky around 4 to 5 percent.”

headline: The Authors of ‘How Democracies Die’ Overestimated the Republicans
abstract: In a new book, they grapple with why Trump turned out to be even worse than they expected.
lead_paragraph: One of the most influential books of the Trump years was “How Democracies Die” by the Harvard government professors Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt. Published in 2018, it served as a guide to our unfolding ordeal. “Over the past two years, we have watched politicians say and do things that are unprecedented in the United States — but that we recognize as having been the precursors of democratic crisis in other places,” they wrote.

headline: Biden Marks 9/11 Anniversary With a Message of Unity
abstract: “It shouldn’t take a national tragedy to remind us of the power of national unity,” President Biden said.
lead_paragraph: President Biden marked the 22nd anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Monday with a message of unity, saying Americans must protect democratic ideals.

headline: America Already Knows How to Make Childbirth Safer
abstract: States can push hospitals to look at California’s model and other proven ways to reduce maternal mortality.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, researchers discovered that American women were dying in childbirth at an alarming rate, far higher than in many other Western countries. Black women, they found, were dying at even more elevated rates. Data in hand, they called for change.

headline: Bulletproof, Slow and Full of Wine: Kim Jong-un’s Mystery Train
abstract: Heading to Russia to meet with President Vladimir Putin, the North Korean leader chose to travel by rail, on a train with some unusual features.
lead_paragraph: When outside intelligence officials seek evidence of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, leaving on a trip abroad — like his journey to Russia this week to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin — they always look for the whereabouts of a train painted a drab green.

headline: Washington University Stops Offering Gender Medications to Minors
abstract: The university cited “unacceptable” legal liability under a new Missouri law.
lead_paragraph: Washington University in St. Louis will stop prescribing gender medications to minors, the school said on Monday, citing “unacceptable” legal liability under a new Missouri law banning such treatments.

headline: After Rodgers’s Injury, the Rest of the Jets Rally to Beat the Bills
abstract: Aaron Rodgers’s Jets debut ended with his departure in the first quarter with an ankle injury. His teammates mustered three interceptions, a crucial touchdown catch and an overtime walk-off touchdown.
lead_paragraph: A half century of Jets dread and gloom was supposed to end Monday night against the Buffalo Bills amid the ceremonious debut of Aaron Rodgers, one of the most prolific passers of his generation. Instead, the Jets’ defense, young receivers and a castaway quarterback, with help from four turnovers from the Bills’ Josh Allen, fueled a 22-16 comeback, overtime win.

headline: ‘Cybersecurity Issue’ Forces Systems Shutdown at MGM Hotels and Casinos
abstract: Company websites were down, and some guests complained of problems with slot machines and hotel room access. Cybersecurity experts point to a likely cyberattack.
lead_paragraph: The casino and hotel chain MGM Resorts International said on Monday that a “cybersecurity issue” was affecting some of its online systems, causing disruptions for customers, particularly in Las Vegas, where cybersecurity experts said the company was likely the victim of a pervasive cyberattack.

headline: Source of Waves in Space
abstract: Ella Dershowitz has us swimming in circles.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Quotation of the Day: Newsom Urges Democrats to ‘Buck Up’ and Back Biden in 2024
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The train has left the station. We’re all in. Stop talking. He’s not going anywhere. It’s time for all of us to get on the train and buck up.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 12, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Iranian American families’ views on education and financial success misstated the grandparent from whom the writer Jason Rezaian received financial support. It was his grandmother, not his grandfather.

headline: Alabama Asks Supreme Court to Revisit Dispute Over Congressional Map
abstract: After a panel of federal judges rejected the state’s proposed congressional district map, the state asked the Supreme Court to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Alabama filed an emergency application in the Supreme Court on Monday evening, asking the justices to keep in place for now a congressional map that a lower court had found failed to comply with orders to establish a second majority-Black district or something “close to it.”

headline: Trump Moves to Quash Most Charges Against Him in Georgia
abstract: The motions piggybacked off others filed by the former president’s co-defendants, one of which gave a detailed critique of the sprawling indictment.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump asked a judge on Monday to throw out most of the 13 charges against him in the wide-ranging election interference indictment handed up by a grand jury last month in Georgia.

headline: State House Candidate in Virginia Condemns Leak of Sex Tapes
abstract: Susanna Gibson, a Democrat running in one of seven tossup House seats in the closely divided legislature, denounced the “illegal invasion of my privacy.”
lead_paragraph: A Democratic candidate in a crucial race for the Virginia General Assembly denounced reports on Monday that she and her husband had performed live on a sexually explicit streaming site.

headline: Talking Heads Reunite for Restored ‘Stop Making Sense’
abstract: Appearing together for the first time since 2002, the band celebrated the film in a Q. and A. with Spike Lee at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: The hottest ticket at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival was not for the new auteur film from Hayao Miyazaki or Ryusuke Hamaguchi, the latest vehicle for Kate Winslet or Sean Penn, or grand prizewinners at Cannes and Venice. No, the most feverishly in-demand screening was for a 39-year-old movie that everyone in its sold-out audience could have watched at home, at the push of a button.

headline: Pennsylvania Fugitive Is Armed, Police Say
abstract: The police are hunting for Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from prison on Aug. 31. He was spotted again on Monday as the search intensified.
lead_paragraph: The police in Pennsylvania said Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison more than 10 days ago, was armed and had been spotted again on Monday night.

headline: Sharks on a Golf Course Made a Watery Grave Unlike Any Other
abstract: A group of bull sharks ended up spending 17 years in a lake by a golf course’s 14th hole, suggesting that the predators can live in low-saltwater environments indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, the Carbrook Golf Club near Brisbane, Australia, had the ultimate water hazard: a lake teeming with bull sharks.

headline: In Ukraine, Mathematics Offers Strength in Numbers
abstract: Mathematicians gathered in Kyiv and Warsaw to inaugurate a new center and “open, or reopen, Ukrainian science for the world.”
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday evening in August, two Ukrainian mathematicians, Maryna Viazovska and Masha Vlasenko, set out on a 19-hour train trip from Warsaw to Kyiv. They were en route to a conference titled “Numbers in the Universe: Recent Advances in Number Theory and Its Applications.” Symbolically, the journey served to plant a flag.

headline: This Museum Has 300 Tanks and Over 100 Million YouTube Views
abstract: Only a few hundred thousand people visit The Tank Museum, in the English countryside, each year. But on YouTube, it’s more popular than the Met and MoMA.
lead_paragraph: The Tank Museum in Bovington, England, doesn’t usually rank among the world’s great museums. Located next to a military base in serene countryside, the collection of around 300 armored vehicles attracts only a few hundred thousand visitors a year, mainly families on rained-out beach vacations.

headline: In a Former Berlin Squat, Slick Photo Shows (and Martinis)
abstract: The Tacheles was once a symbol of underground culture. But with the arrival of Fotografiska, a profit-driven Swedish photography center, the atmosphere has changed.
lead_paragraph: On a cold, gray Berlin afternoon in February, 1990, a few months after the Wall came down, a group of young artists and anarchists from East Germany climbed through the window of an abandoned department store and began creating their own utopia.

headline: A Rush to Build Defenses in Europe, but Little Consensus on How
abstract: A push by more than 30 allied countries to arm themselves, precipitated in part by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, has raised concerns of disorganization and supply shortages.
lead_paragraph: At Saab’s sprawling combat production center in Karlskoga, Sweden, the 84-millimeter shells that can take out a battle tank in a single stroke are carefully assembled by hand. One worker stacked tagliatelle-shaped strips of explosive propellant in a tray. Another attached the translucent sheafs around the rotating fins of a guiding system.

headline: Germany’s Oldest Hops Thrived for Centuries. Then Came Climate Change.
abstract: Hotter, drier seasons are threatening the traditions of German hops growers, who are fighting to preserve a way of life — and the flavor of your favorite brew.
lead_paragraph: Generations of farmers in the sun-lashed green hills of Spalt have proudly tended to their hops plants, used for brewing beer, since the Middle Ages.

headline: Refreshing an Old Mural With a New Dog and Cat
abstract: A wall in SoHo was painted by the artist Richard Haas. Now a team of painters will bring it back to life, adding two animals who live in the building.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out why an old wall in SoHo is getting a new old look. We’ll also get details on the first steps toward a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River that would end train travelers’ dependence on two crumbling tubes built more than a century ago.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Recovery efforts in Morocco.
lead_paragraph: For days after a deadly earthquake left their village in rubble, the people of Douar Tnirt, a remote village in Morocco’s Atlas Mountains, were left alone to dig out and bury victims. Officials and emergency responders were nowhere in sight.

headline: Israel’s Supreme Court Weighs Law That Limits Its Own Power
abstract: Israel’s government passed a bill in July limiting judicial influence. The Supreme Court began meeting on Tuesday to decide whether to strike down the bill, potentially setting up a constitutional crisis.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Supreme Court convened on Tuesday to begin considering whether to strike down a deeply contentious law that limits the court’s own power, in a hearing that sets the stage for a constitutional showdown between the country’s judicial and executive branches.

headline: Word of the Day: unwieldy
abstract: This word has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word unwieldy has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 13 in “Her Qualification for Leading U.S. Soccer? She Never Stopped Winning” by Bruce Schoenfeld:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Could $2,000 a Year Keep Students in College?
abstract: New York’s public university system is starting a program that uses simple strategies, like transportation money, to keep students enrolled and on the path to graduation.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Ramlakhan, 37, has a goal: She wants to become a psychologist and open a private practice with flexible, family-friendly hours to help troubled teenagers. But until two years ago, between family and work, she hadn’t managed to make it through even one full semester of college.

headline: Michelin’s Coveted Stars Can Come With Some Costs
abstract: As its universe of dining guides expands to new places, the company is asking those regions to help pay the bill. And some chefs fear the honors are fostering a world of restaurant clones.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Caroline Glover heard in June that Michelin would be publishing a restaurant guide to Colorado, she was thrilled at first.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Repatriate Family of 10 Americans From Camps in Syria
abstract: A Kurdish-led militia that is battling the Islamic State has been holding a mother and nine of her children for several years.
lead_paragraph: The State Department is working to repatriate a family of 10 American citizens stranded in Syria, where they are among the tens of thousands of people effectively imprisoned in desert camps and detention centers from the war against the Islamic State, according to officials.

headline: TikTok Popularizes Products. Can It Sell Them, Too?
abstract: The company is beginning to introduce TikTok Shop to all of the app’s users in the U.S., hoping to add a major new revenue stream.
lead_paragraph: TikTok wooed marketers from companies like Madewell, H&M and Gucci last Wednesday as part of New York Fashion Week, transforming the stylish East Village restaurant Cathédrale with a video wall showcasing fashion trends like “little luxuries” and tall mannequins wearing TikTok-inspired styles.

headline: Football Season
abstract: Which teams, players and matchups do you have your eye on?
lead_paragraph: Football is back. Will you be watching or playing this fall?

headline: ‘Zombie Trout’ Unsettle Montana, Long a Fly-Fishing Mecca
abstract: Warming waters and other factors along the state’s rivers like the Big Hole appear to be contributing to alarmingly low numbers of the state’s renowned rainbow and brown trout.
lead_paragraph: WISE RIVER, Mont. — Since the Fellin family founded the Big Hole Lodge in the 1980s to take people fly fishing on the Big Hole River, they have seen significant changes to the cobble-and-boulder-studded freestone trout stream.

headline: Can India Challenge China for Leadership of the ‘Global South’?
abstract: A rising India has moved aggressively to champion developing nations, pursuing compromise in polarized times and promising to make America listen.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, China has courted developing countries frustrated with the West. Beijing’s rise from poverty was a source of inspiration. And as it challenged the postwar order, especially with its global focus on development through trade, loans and infrastructure projects, it sent billions of much-needed dollars to poor nations.

headline: Maria Ressa, Journalist and Nobel Laureate, Is Cleared of Tax Fraud
abstract: It was the latest legal victory for the veteran journalist and her news site, Rappler, who have faced a barrage of charges from the Philippine government.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize-winning journalist Maria Ressa on Tuesday was acquitted by a Philippine court of tax fraud, the latest legal victory in her fight for the survival of her news site Rappler, which has come to represent the precariousness of the nation’s press freedoms.

headline: Kim-Putin Meeting Nears, but Where?
abstract: Russian reports said the North Korean leader had crossed into Russia by train on Tuesday morning, but his destination was unclear.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un arrived in Russia on Tuesday, the Kremlin confirmed, traveling aboard his slow-moving armored train to a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin that could see the two nations increasing military cooperation.

headline: To Save My Sister, and Myself, I Had to Walk Away
abstract: Two siblings learn to balance love and self-preservation.
lead_paragraph: Two siblings learn to balance love and self-preservation.

headline: A Rich, Capacious Family Saga, Bookended by Tragedy
abstract: In Diana Evans’s new novel, “A House for Alice,” a woman who immigrated to Britain for marriage must decide whether or not to return to her country of origin after her husband dies.
lead_paragraph: Houses in Diana Evans’s new novel, “A House for Alice,” are a metaphor for family. They’re filled with rooms for sleeping, lovemaking, fighting; contain corridors that lead to areas of welcome and comfort; shelter spaces that hold secrets. And like a house, a family can be burned to nothing and rebuilt anew.

headline: When the Portal to Space Travel Opened, ‘The Six’ Stepped Through
abstract: In a group portrait of America’s first female astronauts, Loren Grush details the basics of training and the challenges of sexism without lionizing her heroines.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to imagine a place more coded as masculine than the cockpit of a rocket ship. The tales of the space race enshrined in American history too often center on white men and elevate machismo. From the first pages of “The Six: The Untold Story of America’s First Women Astronauts,” the science journalist Loren Grush reclaims this place as female.

headline: Where Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Delivers His Fringe Views: Not on the Trail
abstract: The Democratic presidential challenger continues to espouse extreme ideas, but has dialed that messaging back in large public forums.
lead_paragraph: In an online meeting with anti-vaccine activists on June 27, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a Democrat running for president, falsely said there was good evidence that vaccine research had caused millions of deaths during the 1918 Spanish flu epidemic. He also claimed that such research could have created Covid-19, H.I.V. and other deadly viruses.

headline: From ‘Data Dumping’ to ‘Webbing’: How Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Sells Misleading Ideas
abstract: The candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination uses logical leaps and rhetorical devices to create false or misleading messages.
lead_paragraph: When Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the anti-vaccine activist running a long-shot campaign for president, tried to warn about vaccine risks during a podcast interview in the early days of the pandemic, he used a rhetorical device known as data dumping that is commonly used by conspiracy theorists.

headline: The Value of an Education That Never Ends
abstract: As society becomes more polarized, the educational spaces for adults to learn from people with different points of view grow rare.
lead_paragraph: For more than 15 years I have presided over my university’s Arrival Day, the time when families drop off their sons and daughters about to start their college career. Every year some parents will take me aside to say they wish they were starting college, and that they’d get a lot more out of the experience now because they’ve become better learners.

headline: 3 Actors, 1 Unshakable Bond
abstract: Jonathan Groff, Lindsay Mendez and Daniel Radcliffe are the heart of the tear-streaked “Merrily We Roll Along” Broadway revival.
lead_paragraph: What promises to be the most passionate love story of the new Broadway season is a tale of three people. Like many triangles, this one involves jealousy, guilt, misunderstanding, recrimination and betrayal.

headline: The New Punk, (La)Horde Style: Working ‘for a Brighter Future’
abstract: This French dance collective presents its bold vision with the Ballet National de Marseille at the Dance Reflections festival.
lead_paragraph: They are three, but they create as one. They work in dance, music, cinema and fashion — worlds they enter in ways both playful and subversive, including choreographing a video for Burberry inspired by “Singin’ in the Rain,” in which blocks of ice crash down from the sky. It weighs in on climate change. Everyone is smiling, but it isn’t sweet.

headline: Should We Really Be Texting for Work?
abstract: Work has already invaded our homes, evenings and weekends. Now it’s coming for the fun part of your phone.
lead_paragraph: Jake Dunlap texts his wife. He texts his pickleball group chat. And in the past five years, he has started texting his co-workers.

headline: Are Index Funds Making the Economy Less Fair?
abstract: “Taming the Street,” by Diana B. Henriques, and “The Problem of Twelve,” by John Coates, tell the story of America’s powerful and unwieldy financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: “The rulers of the exchange of mankind’s goods have failed, through their own stubbornness and their own incompetence,” President Franklin D. Roosevelt said at his first inaugural in 1933 as he kicked off his New Deal. “The money changers have fled from their high seats in the temple of our civilization. We may now restore that temple to the ancient truths.”

headline: I Drink Alcohol Regularly. What Can I Do to Mitigate the Risks?
abstract: There’s no magic antidote, but experts say certain lifestyle choices can help.
lead_paragraph: Q: I drink alcohol regularly. Are there any healthy activities I can do to counteract its harms?

headline: What Happens on Page 76 in This Season’s Books?
abstract: The artist Mosie Romney envisions new releases by Major Jackson, Ayana Mathis and more.
lead_paragraph: “Rhythm? Where is“Parker’s horn?“In any event, we flaunt“The stuff of old

headline: A Painter of Japan’s ‘Lost Decade,’ Finally Found
abstract: Tetsuya Ishida’s prescient and terrifying works arrive in New York.
lead_paragraph: Observers of the world economy call the 1990s in Japan the Lost Decade. Following what the Washington Post would describe as “an orgy of easy credit and speculation” at the end of the 1980s, residential land values in urban areas became so inflated that, as a former New York Times business editor would argue years later, the “Imperial Palace in downtown Tokyo was believed to be worth as much as the entire state of California.” When the bubble finally burst, in 1991, unemployment and bankruptcies rose. Suicides increased as well. As with many economic calamities, adolescents and young adults were especially impacted, having to support themselves on low wages that were hard to come by. They became collectively known as the “Employment Ice Age Generation.”

headline: Biden’s New ‘New Deal’ Falls Short in Two Critical Areas
abstract: What the current president can learn from Franklin Roosevelt’s “New Deal.”
lead_paragraph: President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s “New Deal” helped raise America’s economy out of the Great Depression in the 1930s and set the country on course to become a superpower. And now, for the first time in decades, we have someone in the White House who has a new New Deal within his grasp.

headline: Sam Heughan’s Glasgow
abstract: The star of ‘Outlander,’ which is halfway through its seventh season, recommends five spots in the Scottish city that he has called home for a decade.
lead_paragraph: “The part of ‘Outlander’ that I love the most is the history: the clan culture, the folklore and back stories (and consequences) of the Jacobite Rising,” said Sam Heughan, 42, who has played the heartthrob Highland warrior Jamie Fraser in the time-travel series since 2014.

headline: Bayard Rustin Challenged Progressive Orthodoxies
abstract: Bayard Rustin has been extolled as an avatar of intersectionality, yet throughout his career he repeatedly challenged progressive orthodoxies.
lead_paragraph: Bayard Rustin, a trusted adviser to Martin Luther King Jr. and chief organizer of the 1963 March on Washington, was a towering figure in the fight for racial equality. Remarkably for a man of his generation and public standing, he was also openly gay. When Mr. Rustin died in 1987, obituaries downplayed or elided this fact. Emblematic of this erasure was this paper, which made only passing mention of his homosexuality and obliquely described Mr. Rustin’s longtime partner as his “administrative assistant and adopted son.”

headline: That Ralph Lauren Feeling
abstract: What does the famed American fashion company have that younger brands are chasing?
lead_paragraph: The clothes are secondary. Almost everyone acknowledges this, including Ralph Lauren himself, who has long been vocal about not considering himself a fashion designer.

headline: A Bathtub in the Kitchen? Not a Problem for New Yorkers.
abstract: The appliances might be miniature and the floor plans eccentric, but these home cooks make it work.
lead_paragraph: Many New York City renters will recognize this scenario: You’re on your fourth apartment tour of the day when a broker unlocks the front door and ushers you into the kitchen. The layout seems unremarkable at first glance, until your eyes dart to the corner. Wait, is that a bathtub?

headline: This Fall, Tartans and Tweeds Get a Modern Twist
abstract: Classic patterns are revitalized with playful silhouettes.

headline: When Club Music Went Commercial, Remixes Kept It Real
abstract: Social justice, romance and gay pride are alive in a sound that would seduce the world.
lead_paragraph: We gathered each Sunday. The place of worship: Tracks, a mammoth warehouse-turned-nightclub in Southeast Washington, D.C. We were a congregation of mostly Black gay men, there to celebrate one another, at a time — the early 1990s — when we were losing so many to AIDS. We danced — many vogued — to the music that endured after the anti-Black, anti-gay “Disco Sucks” movement of the late 1970s. This fledgling genre transformed dance music, through synthesizers, drum machines and the scrappiness of youth, into a sound that would seduce the world. Some would “call it house,” as the duo Mass Order sang on “Lift Every Voice (Take Me Away),” from 1991.

headline: To Save My Sister, and Myself, I Had to Walk Away
abstract: Two siblings learn to balance love and self-preservation.
lead_paragraph: How much are you prepared to lose yourself in someone else’s pain?

headline: How the Supreme Court Should Respond to Alabama’s Defiance
abstract: Can the court be viewed as in any sense standing outside politics?
lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges last week issued a scathing opinion directing the state of Alabama to comply with the Voting Rights Act. It was the latest development in a saga in which the state has repeatedly flouted the requirements of the Voting Rights Act and the rulings of federal courts, up to and including the Supreme Court.

headline: SoftBank Needs a Hit, and It’s Betting on Arm
abstract: Softbank’s chief executive, Masayoshi Son, believes the chip design company he bought in 2016 is poised to reap the fruits of the A.I. revolution.
lead_paragraph: Masayoshi Son, the chief executive and billionaire founder of the tech conglomerate SoftBank, believed so strongly in Arm, the British chip design company he bought in 2016 for $32 billion, that he guaranteed some big investors they wouldn’t lose money on the deal.

headline: Every Bedroom Needs Storage. But What if You Don’t Have Big Closets?
abstract: There are ways to make room for storage in even the smallest bedrooms — and those without any closets at all. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’re not a fashionista, your bedroom needs to hold a lot. Clothing takes up space. So do books and jewelry, not to mention things like extra sheets and blankets.

headline: Why Are We Obsessed With the Destruction of L.A.?
abstract: A video appeared to show Dodger Stadium in ruins. Was it a religious sign, climate disaster or something else entirely?
lead_paragraph: The clip is short — about 30 seconds — yet it evokes an entire Hollywood history. Posted to Los Angeles Dodgers Aerial Photography, a little-followed account on X, formerly known as Twitter, it opens on an out-of-focus shot of Dodger Stadium, filmed through a rain-slicked helicopter window. The rhythmic thump of propellers is the only sound we hear. Eventually the camera focuses, and we see what it is we’re meant to see: The stadium appears as if it’s sitting in the middle of a moat amid Elysian Park’s sparse red-brown hills. Its iconic palm trees jut out of the water like props in a postapocalyptic movie. In the background, the downtown skyline emerges from a pillowy haze.

headline: What Ancient Greek Tragedies Can Teach Us About Grief
abstract: Seeing works by Sophocles and Aeschylus in their native land imparts indelible lessons about pain and memory.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, art precedes life. The word “landscape,” for instance, originally meant a painting, and only later also the land itself. In a similar way, “tragedy” originated onstage, as a dramatic form, before acquiring the more general meaning of a devastating or unfortunate situation. What we now think of as Greek tragedy is a relatively small corpus from the fifth century B.C., fewer than three dozen plays from the hundreds that were produced over the course of that century.
