abstract: The move, announced late Wednesday, followed intense lobbying by New York Democrats before and during President Biden’s visit to New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said late Wednesday that it would allow hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans already in the United States to live and work legally in the country for 18 months.

headline: Peso Pluma Cancels Tijuana Concert After Threats
abstract: The singer-songwriter has helped lead an international surge in what is known in the United States as regional Mexican music. He is best known for corridos tumbados, songs that tell stories of the Mexican drug trade.
lead_paragraph: Peso Pluma, the Mexican singer-songwriter who burst onto the global stage earlier this year, said safety concerns had forced him to cancel his Oct. 14 show in Tijuana, Mexico, just over a week after he was the apparent target of threats from a drug cartel.

headline: This Tiny Parasitic Wasp Can Drill Through Plastic
abstract: In experiments under his microscope at home, a teenage researcher discovered a very unusual talent in a species of tiny insect that usually lays eggs on the inside of a tough plant growth.
lead_paragraph: By the time Matvey Nikelshparg was 13, he was obsessed with parasitoid wasps, tiny insects that lay their eggs on or inside other bugs. Under a microscope in a lab he had assembled at home, he discovered that one species had a startling superpower: It could use an organ that protrudes from its abdomen to drill through a plastic petri dish.

headline: Hong Kong Says It Calls the Shots, Not Beijing. Investors Are Wary.
abstract: Its close ties to Beijing are putting the city, still an international financial hub, in a bind as it lures Western investors to revive its economy.
lead_paragraph: Isolated from the world and pulled closer into Beijing’s orbit over the past three years, Hong Kong is finding that its fortunes are tied more than ever to China.

headline: A ‘Really Online’ Writer Looks Beyond the Internet
abstract: Eliza Clark’s debut novel was a hit on TikTok. With her next book, “Penance,” she aims for literary longevity over viral success.
lead_paragraph: When videos about Eliza Clark’s debut novel “Boy Parts” started going viral on TikTok, she tried to ignore it, at first.

headline: Darfur’s New Generation, Once Full of Promise, Now Suffers ‘Fire of War’
abstract: In a region with a history of genocide, weeks of intense fighting between rival military factions in South Darfur have left hundreds dead and sent thousands fleeing.
lead_paragraph: The news he had dreaded arrived a few minutes before midnight.

headline: Biden Plan Seeks to Keep Migrants Away From the Border. Will It Work?
abstract: By opening migration processing centers in three Latin American countries, the Biden administration is trying to coax people not to make a harrowing trek to the border.
lead_paragraph: As the Biden administration struggles to tackle a humanitarian and political crisis at America’s doorstep, it is focusing increasingly on keeping migrants far from the U.S.-Mexico border by establishing migration processing centers in Central and South America.

headline: A Museum With a Timely Theme Reopens Today
abstract: The Tenement Museum looks at the experience of waves of immigrants in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at a museum whose reopening amid the migrant crisis seems particularly timely. We’ll also see why the man who controls the Knicks and the Rangers is not focused on New York right now.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Climate at the U.N. General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, convened a special summit yesterday in New York designed to shine a spotlight on the most ambitious global leaders on climate policy. The leaders of the U.S. and China, the world’s biggest polluters, did not get a turn at the microphone, and the summit yielded little in the way of new announcements of climate action.

headline: Word of the Day: elocution
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word elocution has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 5 in “Gordon Lightfoot’s 10 Essential Songs” by Rob Tannenbaum:

headline: Missile Strike Hits Cherkasy, Ukraine
abstract: The State Emergency Service of Ukraine released footage of rescue operations following the attack and said that people may still be under the rubble of a building.
lead_paragraph: The State Emergency Service of Ukraine released footage of rescue operations following the attack and said that people may still be under the rubble of a building.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Tiny Homes
abstract: Would you want to live in one?
lead_paragraph: The internet is awash with popular videos of microapartments and tiny homes. Would you want to live in one?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: She Fights for Migrants and the Homeless. Could That Destroy Her Dream?
abstract: Once the city’s second-most powerful politician, Christine Quinn is now a high-profile advocate on the divisive homelessness and migrant crises. That could threaten her chances with future voters.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn was impatient. The leader of New York City’s largest provider of shelter for homeless families with children, she peered over her fuchsia reading glasses at her team, assembled in a conference room, and rattled off a list of instructions.

headline: And Just Like That, Fendi Goes Beyond the Baguette
abstract: It’s not only about the handbag any more. Kim Jones is making great clothes.
lead_paragraph: Four elephantine handbags cast their long shadows over the Fendi runway on a breezy Wednesday as Milan Fashion Week began.

headline: Syria’s Leader Visits China in Search of Friends and Funds
abstract: The trip by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, his first to China since 2004, may bolster Beijing’s efforts to expand its influence in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria arrived in China on Thursday as he sought financial support to rebuild his country and to improve his international standing after being ostracized over atrocities committed during Syria’s ongoing civil war.

headline: 36 Hours in Santiago, Chile
abstract: Against the arresting backdrop of the Andes, the Chilean capital is alive with music, art and nightlife.
lead_paragraph: Against the arresting backdrop of the Andes, the Chilean capital is alive with music, art and nightlife.

headline: Lawrence Wright Sees Books as ‘Creatures of Their Time’
abstract: “I often look back on a book I thought was wonderful and inspiring and found it to be maudlin and flowery or have some other defect of character I overlooked,” says the journalist, whose new book is the novel “Mr. Texas.” “It could be that literary fashions have changed or I’ve gotten older, and of course both are true.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Workers’ Movements or Tantrums Against Technology?
abstract: Brian Merchant’s “Blood in the Machine” compares the labor struggles of the Industrial Revolution to today’s abusive gig economy.
lead_paragraph: Revolutions inevitably birth counterrevolutions. The Industrial Revolution was no exception. In the early 19th century, textile workers in the north of England, set on a course toward obsolescence by new machines, struck back. Under the banner of a mythical apprentice named “Ned Ludd,” they staged nightly factory raids, using massive hammers to smash machines and forcing the British government to place the entire region under military occupation. Ever since, the Luddite movement has spawned mythologies of its own, drawing in writers attracted to its doomed Romantic broadsides against modernity, and its status as a militant workers’ movement erupting at the dawn of industrial capitalism.

headline: Want to Attend an Indian Wedding? Now You Can Pay To.
abstract: Join My Wedding allows tourists to purchase tickets to Indian weddings. Some say it’s resulted in meaningful cultural exchange. Others believe selling the experience can be cultural fetishism.
lead_paragraph: One evening after a long day at work, Diksha Manocha was idly scrolling Instagram when she stumbled across something peculiar: an account for Join My Wedding, an online service that allows tourists to purchase tickets to weddings in India.

headline: ‘Only God Can Thank You’: Female Health Workers Fight to Be Paid
abstract: Community health workers put in long hours to protect people in developing countries from diseases such as malaria, Covid-19 and H.I.V. But most are compensated minimally, or not paid at all.
lead_paragraph: On a given work day, Misra Yusuf might vaccinate a child against polio, inject a woman with a long-acting contraceptive, screen a man for tuberculosis, hang a bed net to protect a family from malaria and help dig a pit latrine. Over the past few years, she has administered some 10,000 coronavirus vaccines in her community in eastern Ethiopia. She has also spotted and snuffed out a measles outbreak.

headline: In Three Southern States, a Legal Battle Over Political Maps
abstract: G.O.P. legislatures in Alabama, Georgia and Louisiana are contesting federal orders to redraw congressional maps that disfavor Black voters. The stakes are enormous.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led legislatures of Georgia, Louisiana and Alabama find themselves backed against courtroom walls this month in strikingly similar circumstances, defending congressional maps that federal judges have said appear to discriminate against Black voters.

headline: Help! The Police Seized My Rental Car and Avis Won’t Refund Me
abstract: A traveler was visiting family when police impounded her vehicle, saying it had been reported stolen. Why wouldn’t Avis give her money back, and why would they rent her a stolen car in the first place?
lead_paragraph: In late May, I flew with my daughter from California to Kennedy International Airport in New York, where I rented a car from Avis and headed to Connecticut for a three-day family visit. On day two, I parked the car in Waveny Park in New Canaan and when I returned, it was gone. The local police told me they had impounded the rental because Avis had reported it stolen to the New York Police Department. I had planned to spend the last day of my trip with my 80-something mother, whom I had not seen for three years because of the pandemic, but had to waste precious hours on hold with Avis’s customer service department. They eventually offered me a new car but I was unable to coordinate picking it up, so we ended up relying on my sisters to get around. I was only able to spend a few hours with my mom and had to take a $100 Uber back to the airport. I asked Avis not to charge me for the rental, but they did, $653, and when I disputed the charge with Capital One, Avis fought me. I can’t believe Avis is renting out cars they have reported stolen, and then charging its clients. Can you help? Lorraine, El Dorado Hills, Calif.

headline: The Era of Prestige TV Is Ending. We’re Going to Miss It When It’s Gone.
abstract: The 2023 Emmys were meant to be a celebration of television’s best. Instead, they’ll serve as a funeral for the era dominated by landmark shows.
lead_paragraph: In a normal year we’d be talking about the 75th Emmy Awards telecast this week: who wore what, whose speech went too long and which of the lauded shows took home the night’s biggest haul. But the awards telecast was postponed to January, in hopes that the writers’ and actors’ strikes will be resolved by then, so we’ll have to wait a few more months to celebrate what was a remarkable year in TV. Twenty-seven nominations for the final season of “Succession” alone, including 14 nominated acting performances. Prestige heavyweights like “Better Call Saul,” “The White Lotus,” “The Last of Us” and “The Crown” all duking it out — and that’s just in the outstanding drama category. What a lineup! What a year!

headline: ‘Cassandro’ Review: Love and Lucha Libre
abstract: Gael García Bernal plays a flamboyant figure taking the world of Mexican professional wrestling by storm in this underdog drama directed by Roger Ross Williams.
lead_paragraph: When Barton Fink, the neurotic screenwriter cooked up by the Coen brothers, scrambles to write a wrestling picture, his peers prescribe the basics. Tell us the man’s ambitions. Entangle him in a romance. You know the drill. Not even in Barton’s most delirious dreams could he have envisioned “Cassandro,” about a flamboyant, sequin-clad luchador who takes his ring name from a telenovela. But I bet Barton could have drafted the film’s outline, which uses the same squelchy gym bag of tricks as many underdog sports dramas.

headline: The Laver Cup Underlines a Generational Shift in Tennis
abstract: Young players are stepping up as some older ones fade. Even Roger Federer, the event’s father, has retired.
lead_paragraph: Coming into this year’s U.S. Open, Ben Shelton felt that he had something to prove. But it didn’t have anything to do with the final major championship of the year, where he reached the semifinals before falling to the eventual winner, Novak Djokovic.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Your Partner Turning Off the Lights You Just Turned On
abstract: You’re just trying not to step on the cat.
lead_paragraph: Gillian writes: My partner routinely turns off lights that I have just turned on, leaving me fumbling around in the dark, trying not to step on the cat. (My eyesight isn’t the best.) He also installed a solar panel on our fire escape and is experimenting with charging his phone with saltwater. I consider myself a conscientious consumer of electricity, too. But sometimes I want the lights on because I need them to see.

headline: Poem: ‘CAIN’
abstract: The easy way of seeing the world begins to look like a socially convenient illusion.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Reines’s poem “CAIN” travels in couplets. Each line is like one foot, then another, falling onto the pavement of the city, and with each step, thought itself moves, then transforms. The easy way of seeing the world begins to look like a socially convenient illusion. In its place is something so shocking — and perhaps shockingly out of fashion — that it requires scare quotes. “The truth,” with all its ancient and uneasy heft, appears. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: Where Parking Costs the Most and the Least
abstract: Paying for one month of parking in New York City would get you almost two years of parking in Tulsa.
lead_paragraph: Anyone looking at property listings in a big city knows that the number of bedrooms and bathrooms is closely followed by another bit of essential information: how many parking spaces are included.

headline: The Only Way College Sports Can Begin to Make Sense Again
abstract: The N.C.A.A. is denying the obvious. It’s time for member schools to act.
lead_paragraph: College sports are in a state of upheaval. As of 2025, the century-old Pacific-12 Conference will no longer exist for all intents and purposes, as U.C.L.A., U.S.C., the University of Washington and the University of Oregon have decamped for bigger paychecks from the Big Ten Conference, and Stanford and the University of California, Berkeley, will henceforth compete in the now ironically named Atlantic Coast Conference.

headline: When It Comes to Sports, Joe Posnanski Is an Old Hand
abstract: The veteran columnist and author has covered athletic endeavors for so long, he’s witnessed a revolution.
lead_paragraph: Sportswriting has changed since Joe Posnanski entered the game (sorry) more than three decades ago. Back then there was a clear path to follow: “You worked your way up from a small paper to a midsize paper to a large paper and you did it by getting better and better and writing about bigger and bigger things,” Posnanski said in a phone interview. “I started as a columnist in Augusta, Ga., and I was the voice of Augusta, Ga. And then I went to Cincinnati and I was one of the voices in Cincinnati.”

headline: Why Do Conservatives Attack Abortion and Trans Rights in the Same Ways?
abstract: Trans people are under attack in America.
lead_paragraph: We were at the sinks in the ladies room, the stranger and I, washing our hands, when a trans woman came out of a stall, looked in the mirror and sighed. After she left, the stranger turned to me and said: “Can you believe that? A man, in here!” She shook her head disapprovingly.

headline: The Precarious Force of Feminist Foreign Policy
abstract: More countries are prioritizing women’s rights and representation, but the movement’s future is far from certain.
lead_paragraph: When Margot Wallstrom, then Sweden’s foreign minister, announced back in 2014 that her country would pursue a feminist foreign policy, the idea was greeted with skepticism. Ms. Wallstrom was criticized by the foreign policy establishment globally for both her openly activist approach and the perception that she was naïve to the realities of realpolitik. As a 2015 New Yorker article put it, “Within the diplomatic community, where words are carefully chosen so as not to offend, ‘feminism’ is usually avoided.”

headline: Inside the Elaborate, Enviable Design of Three New York Homes
abstract: On Washington Square Park, in Harlem and on the coast in Montauk, several creative people renovate their spaces with an essential New York trait in mind: resourcefulness.
lead_paragraph: On Washington Square Park, in Harlem and on the coast in Montauk, several creative people renovate their spaces with an essential New York trait in mind: resourcefulness.

headline: A Wood-Lined Apartment on Washington Square Park
abstract: In Greenwich Village, a photographers’ agent creates a moody home that captures the spirit of a city that’s always building on top of itself.
lead_paragraph: In Greenwich Village, a photographers’ agent creates a moody home that captures the spirit of a city that’s always building on top of itself.

headline: In Harlem, a Crumbling Former Rectory Finds New Life
abstract: How an artist turned a neo-Gothic townhouse uptown into a modern, spacious home.
lead_paragraph: How an artist turned a neo-Gothic townhouse uptown into a modern, spacious home.

headline: The Lawyers Sam Bankman-Fried Once Trusted Are Drawing Criticism
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried and his allies have blasted Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York law firm managing FTX’s bankruptcy, for its tangled relationship with the crypto exchange.
lead_paragraph: Just before FTX collapsed in November, one of its outside lawyers at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell emailed a colleague at another firm, insisting that the cryptocurrency exchange’s finances were stable.

headline: Julianne Moore’s Montauk Sanctuary
abstract: In a wild meadow by the sea, the actress and her husband, Bart Freundlich, use few materials to say many things.
lead_paragraph: In a wild meadow by the sea, the actress and her husband, Bart Freundlich, use few materials to say many things.

headline: The Borking of Joe Biden
abstract: The impeachment inquiry is just the latest twisted Republican abuse of Democratic precedent.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that the Republican House was no more sophisticated than a preschool playground, last week’s opening of an impeachment inquiry into President Biden settled it with a nasty kick of sand in Democrats’ face.

headline: In Washington Visit, Zelensky Tries to Shore Up Critical Support
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky told lawmakers that Ukraine would lose the war to Russia if the United States curtailed the flow of aid and weapons.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday that the United States would be “staying with you” as its grinding war with Russia continues, even as a growing faction of the Republican Party has threatened to hold up aid that Mr. Zelensky said could cost his country the war.

headline: In Phoenix, a Classics Professor Goes on a Home-Buying Odyssey. Which One Did She Choose?
abstract: For her first home purchase, an associate professor at Arizona State hoped to find something for less than $400,000, with a little history to it.
lead_paragraph: For her first home purchase, an associate professor at Arizona State hoped to find something for less than $400,000, with a little history to it.

headline: It’s Not a Race, Yet, in the Republican Primary
abstract: Donald Trump is polling about as well as any candidate in the modern history of contested presidential primaries.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s lead in the Republican primary just keeps growing.

headline: Today’s Top News: McCarthy Won’t Host Forum for Zelensky, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Canada Confronts India Over Alleged Assassination
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s accusation has further soured relations between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: India Suspends Visas for Canadians, Escalating Clash Over Sikh’s Killing
abstract: The move followed Canada’s claim of Indian government involvement in the assassination of a Canadian citizen who supported a separatist cause.
lead_paragraph: India has suspended visa applications by Canadian nationals, a sharp escalation in the diplomatic conflict that has followed Canada’s claim that Indian agents were behind an assassination in June on Canadian soil.

headline: Life at 13
abstract: A behind-the-scenes look at teenagers’ use of social media.
lead_paragraph: London, a 13-year-old girl who lives in suburban Maryland, took a more considered approach to joining social media than many teenagers do. Knowing her mom was skeptical, London put together a presentation making a case for why she should join TikTok, complete with promises such as allowing her mother to review her posts in advance. It worked: On London’s 13th birthday, she joined TikTok.

headline: After Surrender in Nagorno-Karabakh, Leaders Discuss Armenians’ Fate
abstract: Officials of the breakaway region met with representatives of Azerbaijan to talk about the future of its residents, many of whom strongly resist the idea of coming under Azerbaijani rule.
lead_paragraph: One day after Azerbaijan used force to assert its authority over a mountainous breakaway region in the South Caucasus, its officials met with representatives of the pro-Armenian enclave on Thursday to discuss the future of the residents there under new rule.

headline: Some Fortnite Players Are Owed Refunds. Here’s How to Claim Yours.
abstract: Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, agreed to pay $245 million to refund customers over accusations that it tricked players into making unwanted purchases.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission has begun notifying more than 37 million people who can now apply to claim a portion of a $245 million settlement with the owner of Fortnite, Epic Games, the agency announced this week.

headline: ‘My Sailor, My Love’ Review: When Romance Comes Ashore
abstract: A grumpy man warms to a good-natured housekeeper in this film directed by Klaus Haro.
lead_paragraph: Howard (James Cosmo), the Irish widower and retired sea captain of Klaus Haro’s bittersweet drama “My Sailor, My Love,” is furious that his daughter has hired a good-natured housekeeper named Annie (Brid Brennan), to disturb his seclusion. At first, the grump does his best to scare off the invader. “Never darken my door again!” he thunders old-fashionedly, as though he’s subconsciously aware that the writers Kirsi Vikman and Jimmy Karlsson are drawing on centuries of love stories about savage men and civilizing women. The production designer John Hand has even worked in a nod to the rose from “Beauty and the Beast.”

headline: ‘26.2 to Life’ Review: Running in Circles
abstract: Christine Yoo’s new documentary follows the inmates of San Quentin Prison in California who train to run a grueling marathon inside its yard.
lead_paragraph: Christine Yoo’s documentary “26.2 to Life” tells the story of a unique race: the San Quentin Prison Marathon, run by inmates of the maximum-security facility in California within the walls of its heavily guarded yard.

headline: ‘Something You Said Last Night’ Review: They Holiday, but Can’t Get Away
abstract: In this too-languid drama, a young transgender woman and her family butt heads during a fraught beach vacation.
lead_paragraph: The family in Luis De Filippis’s assiduous new film keeps busy during their beachside vacation. Not by swimming and sunbathing but by bickering and nit-picking, over slights both big (what it means to quit school) and small (what it means to lose a card game).

headline: ‘Neither Confirm Nor Deny’ Review: Exhumation at Sea
abstract: A 1970s submarine recovery operation by the C.I.A. is the subject of this documentary, which prioritizes the excitement of undercover work over any serious consideration of the agency’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. mission recalled in “Neither Confirm Nor Deny,” Philip Carter’s neat and steadily paced documentary, sounds like the stuff of a Tom Clancy Cold War thriller. In the film, C.I.A. veterans and journalists recount a 1974 U.S. operation to recover a Soviet nuclear submarine that had sunk in the Pacific six years earlier. It’s a high-risk mission made more suspenseful by technical challenges, the looming specter of Watergate and a need for secrecy in the face of scrutiny from Russia and the press.

headline: ‘It Lives Inside’ Review: The Horrors of Building Self-Acceptance
abstract: This feature debut about a high schooler’s struggle with her cultural identity is promising, even if the allegory doesn’t always land.
lead_paragraph: Why did you even come here, Samidha scoffs at her mother, if you were just going to be another Desi housewife? It’s about as piercing a jab as an American child could throw at their immigrant parent, and emblematic of the kind of disdain central to “It Lives Inside,” a social-horror movie from the writer-director Bishal Dutta, in his feature debut.

headline: ‘Still Film’ Review: Hollywood on Trial
abstract: James N. Kienitz Wilkins’s eloquently argued experimental film warns of a contemporary Hollywood dangerously obsessed with the past.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever had a memory of a memory?” The question comes from an unseen prosecutor. His beleaguered witness, flummoxed, recalls once taking a friend’s story (a bizarre tale about a pervert giving away free bologna on a street corner) and presenting it as his own. Juxtaposed with the dialogue is a still from “The Sandlot,” the 1993 family comedy.

headline: ‘The Storms of Jeremy Thomas’ Review: A Man Obsessed
abstract: Thomas’s dedication to pushing the envelope of big-screen entertainment is the focus of Mark Cousins’s latest documentary.
lead_paragraph: If you’re familiar with a certain streak of transgressive independent cinema, you’re likely familiar with the films of the producer Jeremy Thomas, even if you don’t know his name: Jonathan Glazer’s “Sexy Beast,” Bernardo Bertolucci’s “The Last Emperor,” Nagisa Oshima’s “Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence” with David Bowie, and several works byDavid Cronenberg and Nicolas Roeg, including Cronenberg’s controversial adaptation of J.G. Ballard’s 1973 novel “Crash.”

headline: ‘The Trial’ Review: Seeking Justice for Argentina
abstract: Ulises de la Orden carves a documentary from film of the 1985 prosecution of the military leaders who had seized control of the government.
lead_paragraph: Crafted entirely out of the televised 1985 trial of Argentina’s military junta, “The Trial” lays bare horrific crimes while showing the courage of victims, survivors and their families. Ulises de la Orden’s conscientious documentary is a necessary act of memory — for such is the only way justice truly endures — and it reminds viewers of the Dante-esque extent of the abuses beyond the stories of “the disappeared,” the thousands who were snatched and killed because they were labeled left-wing opponents or on other pretexts.

headline: Powdered Hair to Hoodies: How Did the Senate Get Here?
abstract: It’s fashion month, but some style news is coming not from the runways, but from the legislative branch of the U.S. government.
lead_paragraph: Just as the fashion world was turning its attention from London to Milan, Washington made some style news of its own: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, announced on Monday a relaxation of the “informal dress code” in the chamber.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Rates Steady for First Time in Nearly Two Years
abstract: After 14 consecutive interest rate increases, the central bank’s long fight against persistent inflation in Britain is entering a new phase.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England left interest rates unchanged on Thursday, the first time in nearly two years that it opted to not raise rates during a long-running battle against stubbornly high inflation.

headline: 9 Deputies Indicted in Death of Man Beaten in Memphis Jail
abstract: Gershun Freeman, 33, died last year after being stomped, punched and pinned down by the deputies in Shelby County, Tenn., his family’s lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Nine sheriff’s deputies in Memphis have been indicted in the death of a man with mental health problems who died in custody last fall after being stomped, punched and pinned down. It is the latest case to draw attention to how law enforcement responds to people in mental distress.

headline: Ukraine Targets Russian-Occupied Crimea With Missiles and Drones
abstract: Ukraine’s military said it attacked a Russian air base near the Crimean city of Saki, but gave no details. Russian officials claimed to have thwarted the aerial assaults.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine fired missiles and drones at the Russian-occupied Crimean Peninsula, Russian and Ukrainian officials said on Thursday, as Moscow’s forces attacked regions across Ukraine.

headline: Book Bans Are Rising Sharply in Public Libraries
abstract: Two years into a surge in book banning efforts across the country, restrictions that were largely happening in school libraries, where they affected children, are now affecting the wider community as well.
lead_paragraph: More than two years into a sharp rise in book challenges across the United States, restrictions are increasingly targeting public libraries, where they could affect not only the children’s section but also the books available to everyone in a community.

headline: Tech Giants See Chatbots Everywhere, Including in Your Inbox
abstract: Google and Amazon have announced a slew of new A.I. offerings this week, and Microsoft is expected to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: Months after OpenAI’s ChatGPT seized the world’s imagination and spurred a global debate about how to regulate artificial intelligence, use of the chatbot has dropped sharply. (Though that may just be tied to students having been on summer vacation.)

headline: Here’s today’s schedule.
abstract: Below is a schedule for the Climate Forward event. Note that times are subject to change.
lead_paragraph: Below is a schedule for the Climate Forward event. Note that times are subject to change.

headline: At This Vending Machine, Four Quarters Get You One Surprise Artwork
abstract: Plus: Mohammed Sami’s paintings of displacement, a new omakase spot — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: An unusual nigiri will soon be on offer at Bar Miller, a new omakase restaurant in New York City’s East Village: the humble bluefish, sourced from the New York-New Jersey coast, served raw. “Bluefish has this reputation as being a lesser tier, like a poor man’s fish. But if you treat it with care, it’s incredible,” says Jeff Miller, the executive chef. “When it’s in season, it’s rich, fatty and buttery, with a little bit of subtle tuna iron quality.” Featuring bluefish on a sushi menu is surprising when the city is awash with omakase that, like those in Tokyo, offer prestigious (but unsustainable, according to Seafood Watch) fish like bluefin tuna, Japanese yellowtail and Japanese eel. “Sometimes I think my life would be so much easier If I’d gone that route,” Miller says in reference to the classic omakase menu for which there are standard suppliers. Instead, through trial and error, he built a menu entirely from domestic fish. Bar Miller, which is set to open on Sept. 27, serves San Franciscan anchovies, Hudson Valley eel head trout, and Long Island porgy. (The latter, Miller says, tastes sweet and “super subtle [with] a deep oceanic flavor.”) Miller’s attention to local delicacies extends beyond marine life: The restaurant’s sushi rice is farmed in the Hudson Valley; its sushi vinegar is fermented in Pennsylvania; its soy sauce comes from Connecticut. Even its sake is hyperlocal, fermented in Sunset Park and Bushwick. For Miller, sourcing locally is about expanding on his lifelong appreciation of Japanese cuisine; sustainability is an attendant benefit. barmiller.com.

headline: The Summer of 2023 Was California’s Coolest in More Than a Decade
abstract: The more moderate weather this year broke a streak of three straight scorching summers, each ranking among the state’s 10 hottest ever recorded.
lead_paragraph: The past summer was the hottest ever in the Northern Hemisphere.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Oceanport, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A six-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 6,585-square-foot stone house built in 1917 and renovated in the early 2000s, with original wood and iron details, a formal living room with a fireplace, an eat-in kitchen, a butler’s pantry, a study, a primary bedroom suite with a fireplace and screened porch, a finished lower level, a flagstone patio, a detached two-car garage and Hudson River views, on 1.2 acres. Suzanne van der Wilden, Berkshire Hathaway Home Services, 917-826-9501; bhhs.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are on Riverside Drive, in Midtown East and in Sheepshead Bay.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-bath 1,450-square-foot co-op with 10-and-a-half-foot ceilings, a kitchen with two sinks and a breakfast bar, an open living and dining area, a primary bedroom with overhead beams and a windowed bathroom, on the first floor of the Peter Stuyvesant, a 12-story building from 1909 with a part-time doorman, live-in super and building manager, a bike room, roof deck, basement storage and shared laundry. Sheila Starr, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, 917-557-1173; nyc.bhhsnyproperties.com

headline: Advances in Eye Scans and Protein Structure Win 2023 Lasker Awards
abstract: This year’s awards were given to scientists who helped doctors see the retina and used artificial intelligence to predict the shapes of cellular proteins.
lead_paragraph: The prestigious Lasker Awards were given on Thursday to scientists making advances in the diagnosis of eye disease, the prediction of cellular protein structure and the intricacies of the immune system. The awards, closely watched by researchers in biomedical fields, often foreshadow Nobel Prizes.

headline: Rupert Murdoch to Retire From Fox and News Corporation Boards
abstract: The move leaves his son Lachlan as the sole executive in charge of the global media empire.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch is retiring from the Fox and News Corporation boards, the companies announced Thursday morning, making his son Lachlan the sole executive in charge of the powerful global media empire he built from a small local newspaper concern in Australia 70 years ago.

headline: As Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash, Russia Is a Distracted Spectator
abstract: In the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, Russia, drained by the war in Ukraine, seemed incapable of acting as the indispensable power capable of knocking heads together.
lead_paragraph: Endorsing yet another cease-fire in the conflict that embroils two of Moscow’s closest partners — Armenia and Azerbaijan — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia “noted with satisfaction” on Wednesday that the Russian peacekeepers he sent to the region to enforce an earlier, failed truce had helped quell the renewed fighting.

headline: China Keeps Trying to Crush Them. Their Movement Keeps Growing.
abstract: Underground historians work under the shadow of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: In 1959, a group of university students in the northwestern Chinese city of Tianshui embarked on a quixotic plan. China was in the midst of the Great Famine, a catastrophe caused by government policies that would kill as many as 45 million. These young people had witnessed farmers starving to death and cannibalism; they also saw how the government had brutally punished or killed people who appealed for help. They felt someone needed to do something to spread word of what was happening. They decided to publish a journal.

headline: A 9/11 Widow’s Plea to Biden Over a U.S.-Saudi Treaty
abstract: A powerful message to the president as the U.S. considers a mutual defense treaty with Saudi Arabia, where several 9/11 terrorists came from.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: As Dispute With Ukraine Escalates, Poland Says It Won’t Send New Weapons
abstract: The Polish prime minister’s comments came as the country’s governing party seeks to reassure voters that it will not put Ukraine’s interests ahead of those of Polish citizens.
lead_paragraph: The Polish authorities said they would supply Ukraine “only” with already promised weapons, the latest in an escalating public dispute between Kyiv and one of its staunchest allies that comes as the ruling party in Warsaw is trying to fend off a far-right competitor ahead of a national election.

headline: Bloomberg Outlines Succession Plan for Bloomberg L.P.
abstract: “At 81 years old, common sense says I should have succession plans,” the former New York City mayor said at The Times’s Climate Summit on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: As he kicks off a new campaign to use his wealth to block the construction of petrochemical plants, Michael R. Bloomberg outlined the fate of his company Bloomberg L.P. after he dies. He said his Bloomberg Philanthropies foundation would inherit his multi-billion-dollar company and then eventually sell it.

headline: How Climate Week in New York Turned Into ‘Burning Man for Climate Geeks’
abstract: From small panel discussions in 2009, Climate Week NYC has ballooned into a weeklong happening of dinners, events, networking and spectacle.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost like the climate crisis has gotten itself a new team of publicists, judging from the boggling array of sessions, panels, VI.P. dinners, workshops and fireside chats happening this week as part of Climate Week NYC.

headline: Bloomberg Says He’s Made Succession Plans for His Company’s Future
abstract: “If you make a lot of money, you have to do something with it,” former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said.
lead_paragraph: “If you make a lot of money, you have to do something with it,” former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said.

headline: Al Gore Says Fossil Fuel Industry Seek to ‘Capture’ Climate Talks
abstract: The former vice president said at The New York Times’s Climate Forward event that oil and gas companies were “using the atmosphere as an open sewer.”
lead_paragraph: Fossil fuel interests are trying to co-opt the battle against climate change, Al Gore warned on Thursday, noting that the United Nations had appointed a top oil executive, Sultan Ahmed al-Jaber of the United Arab Emirates, to lead this year’s global climate talks.

headline: A Quick Corn Pasta That’s Just as Delicious the Next Day
abstract: And a blistered tomato dressing to prolong that summer tomato magic.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark’s new recipe for pasta with corn, mint and red onions has a lot going for it. It’s quick — only 25 minutes or so from start to finish — and it’s vegetarian, making it an excellent weeknight option for anyone leaning into a plant-based diet. It ticks all the flavor boxes: sweet kernels of corn, refreshing mint, piquant onion and acidic tomatoes. And it’s just as delicious eaten at room temperature (or even cold) as it is straight from the pan, making for a desk lunch your co-workers will covet.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 4, 2023
abstract: Why is the cumulative force of head hits in football so dangerous?
lead_paragraph: Note: A live moderated discussion of this graph will take place on Oct. 4.

headline: A Tiananmen Square Musical Worries About China’s Glare
abstract: The original lead actor and director withdrew from the Phoenix production of a show about the 1989 pro-democracy protests, a topic that China aggressively censors.
lead_paragraph: When it was announced that Zachary Noah Piser would be playing the lead role in “Tiananmen: A New Musical,” he happened to be on a concert tour of five Chinese cities with a group of Broadway actors.

headline: Earth’s Hottest August on Record Followed a Record-Breaking June and July
abstract: U.S. government scientists also reported a fifth consecutive monthly record for global sea surface temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Temperature records continue to topple. Last month was the planet’s warmest August in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s 174-year record, agency officials said on Thursday. The global surface temperature for the month was 2.25 degrees Fahrenheit, or 1.25 degrees Celsius, above the 20th century average.

headline: ‘Lunar Eclipse’ Review: A Dark, Cloudy Night of the Soul
abstract: In Donald Margulies’s heavy-handed new play, Reed Birney is terrific as a farmer forced by his wife, played by Karen Allen, to face his grief.
lead_paragraph: “We realize he’s crying” must be among the scariest stage directions an actor could find at the top of a script. How do you get from zero to tears with no context?

headline: Discontent With Party Politics Reaches New Heights
abstract: Americans tend to agree on what is wrong with the political system, and majorities of voters from both parties are unhappy with the quality of the candidates. But there also seems to be little appetite for third-party candidates.
lead_paragraph: Close to one year away from the 2024 presidential election, most Americans say they are discontent with their candidate choices, and 28 percent of Americans say they do not like either political party, quadruple the share that said the same thing 30 years ago.

headline: ‘Tired of Losing’: Pennsylvania G.O.P. Aims to Avoid Senate Infighting
abstract: Brutal primary fights weakened the party’s nominees in several states last year. Now, as David McCormick runs again for Senate in the battleground state, he appears to have cleared the field.
lead_paragraph: To avoid costly Senate battleground defeats in 2024, Republicans have a plan: run like Democrats.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Final Chapter: Peanut Butter Ice Cream and His 99th Birthday
abstract: Mr. Carter was already the longest-living president in American history, but his staying power even in hospice has captured the imagination of admirers around the world.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the peanut butter ice cream he still enjoys. Or the fact that his first-place Atlanta Braves are cruising toward the playoffs and he wants to see another World Series. Or as many of his loved ones and former advisers suggest, maybe he is just too stubborn to follow anyone else’s timetable.

headline: Residents See Signs of Crackdown on Dissent After Libya Floods
abstract: Several people have been arrested and some journalists and aid workers have been shut out of the eastern city of Derna after dams burst, killing thousands. Communications have also been disrupted.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in flood-devastated eastern Libya appeared to be moving to muzzle dissent over the past week, arresting protesters and activists who have demanded accountability for what they say was a botched official response to the catastrophe.

headline: Mexico Feels Pressure of Relentless Migration From South America
abstract: The surge of migrants trekking north mostly from South America has placed increasing pressure on Mexico as the country applies a range of tactics to quell arrivals.
lead_paragraph: At a Mexico City shelter, the nun in charge made another difficult announcement to the mothers and children arriving Wednesday: There was no more space. Five hundred migrants were already crammed into a facility built for 100.

headline: Worries About Climate Change Should Spur Us to Action
abstract: Responses to articles about America’s energy policies and “eco-anxiety.” Also: Kevin McCarthy’s snub of Volodymyr Zelensky; Merrick Garland; the Birmingham bombing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Yards, Offices and Basements, New York Hopes to Build 100,000 Homes
abstract: As New York’s housing crisis rages, Mayor Eric Adams is proposing broad changes that would make it easier to build above commercial strips, near subway stations and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams proposed on Thursday a major overhaul of New York City’s approach to development that his administration says could make way for as many as 100,000 additional homes in the coming years and ease the city’s severe housing crisis.

headline: ‘Fossil Fuel Industries Speak With Forked Tongue,’ Al Gore Says
abstract: Former Vice President Al Gore called out duplicitous tactics used by fossil fuel companies to steer climate talks, during a conversation at The New York Times’s Climate Forward event.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Al Gore called out duplicitous tactics used by fossil fuel companies to steer climate talks, during a conversation at The New York Times’s Climate Forward event.

headline: ‘Dig’ Review: At This Shop, Nurturing Plants and Weary Souls
abstract: Theresa Rebeck’s play, a Primary Stages production at 59E59 Theaters, is a beautifully acted dramedy exploring the truth and warped perceptions of it.
lead_paragraph: Amid the thriving greenery of an indie plant shop called Dig, two living organisms are only tenuously clinging to survival.

headline: In ‘American Horror Story,’ Kim Kardashian Skims the Surface
abstract: In her debut on Wednesday night, Kardashian seemed to treat the series with the same unblinking resolve she applies to any business venture.
lead_paragraph: Kim Kardashian is a reality star, a tabloid sensation, a prison-reform advocate, a beauty and shapewear mogul and a former video vixen. As of Wednesday night, she is also a member of the Ryan Murphy extended universe, with a series regular role in FX’s “American Horror Story: Delicate.” (It is also streaming on Hulu.) She plays Siobhan, the high-gloss publicist employed by Emma Roberts’s Anna Victoria Alcott, an actress attempting an Oscar campaign as she undergoes a third cycle of in vitro fertilization.

headline: Ethan Hawke Makes Peace With Being a Poster Boy for Gen X
abstract: At the Center for Fiction, the actor was joined by the author Rachel Kushner and the editor Christopher Beha for a panel discussion of Harper’s Magazine’s September issue.
lead_paragraph: Onstage at the Center for Fiction in Brooklyn on Monday night, Ethan Hawke said that for many years he felt “angry” whenever he was asked about Gen X.

headline: Where to Drink Wine in the Hudson Valley
abstract: The emergent food culture of the region includes wonderful restaurants and cafes. Here are seven places to visit.
lead_paragraph: In the last 15 years or so, a growing number of people have come to see the Hudson Valley as more than a beautiful place to visit. They have moved there full time, joining those who have long made it their home.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Ophelia
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Post-tropical Cyclone Ophelia.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Post-tropical Cyclone Ophelia.

headline: Polls Show Ron DeSantis Sliding in the Republican Primary
abstract: Several recent surveys, nationally and in early-voting states, undermine the governor’s argument that the primary is a two-way race between him and former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Several recent polls show Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida losing ground in the Republican presidential primary, both nationally and in early-voting states.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Chinese Cinema and More
abstract: I’m a China correspondent for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been reading, watching and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a China correspondent for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been reading, watching and listening to.

headline: Right-Wing Rebels Block Defense Bill Again, Rebuking McCarthy on Spending
abstract: It was the second time in a week that hard-right Republicans had defied Speaker Kevin McCarthy on a spending measure, signaling that the G.O.P. was still far from agreement on a bill to fund the government.
lead_paragraph: Right-wing House Republicans dealt another stunning rebuke to Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Thursday, blocking a Pentagon funding bill for the second time this week in a vivid display of G.O.P. disunity on federal spending that threatens to lead to a government shutdown in nine days.

headline: Will Work Authorization Draw More Venezuelan Migrants to the U.S.?
abstract: The Biden administration will grant work permits to hundreds of thousands of migrants, a move welcomed by the leaders of big cities, especially New York.
lead_paragraph: Is it a case of a wish come true or “be careful what you wish for”?

headline: For Tesla and Musk, Auto Strike Carries Benefits and Risks
abstract: Elon Musk, the Tesla chief executive, may be able to exploit his rivals’ weaknesses, but the United Automobile Workers union also has the electric carmaker in its sights.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers strike against the Michigan automakers would seem to be nothing but good news for Tesla, the electric vehicle maker that has upended the industry and stolen customers from Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis, which owns Jeep and Ram.

headline: Residents of Kyiv Sift Through the Aftermath of a Missile Attack
abstract: In the Darnytsia neighborhood of the Ukrainian capital, residents were retrieving their belongings and sweeping up broken glass.
lead_paragraph: Residents of a two-story building in Kyiv were woken in their beds by a missile attack that gouged a crater less than 50 yards from their home early Thursday.

headline: The Spotlight Shines on the Rugby World Cup in France
abstract: French fans have packed out stadiums, the Place de la Concorde and other venues to show their support for rugby in a land where soccer rules.
lead_paragraph: Rugby fans love their game. But most of the time it is overshadowed by the behemoth that is soccer. So once every four years, when the two-month-long Rugby World Cup gets underway, it’s a rare chance for rugby to bask in the sports spotlight.

headline: Gita Mehta, Whose Writing Shaped Perspectives of India, Dies at 80
abstract: Her novels and nonfiction provided alternatives to the Western- and male-centric views of modern India offered by writers like E.M. Forster.
lead_paragraph: Gita Mehta, whose books examined the impact of Western culture on modern India and vice versa, bringing an Indian and a woman’s perspective to subject matter that was long the province of white men, died on Saturday at her home in New Delhi. She was 80.

headline: Cisco to Buy Splunk, a Software Company, for $28 Billion
abstract: The largest deal Cisco has ever announced moves it further away from its roots in network hardware and into higher-margin software subscriptions.
lead_paragraph: Cisco agreed on Thursday to buy Splunk, a data-analysis software company, for $28 billion in cash, as technology giants continue to look to acquisitions as a way to grow — particularly in hot sectors like artificial intelligence.

headline: TikTok Star Sentenced to Prison After Eating Pork on Camera
abstract: Lina Lutfiawati, an influencer from Indonesia, received a two-year sentence after a video of her eating pork rinds angered the nation’s ​​top Muslim clerics.
lead_paragraph: Lina Lutfiawati’s videos of eating delectable meals — featuring fish, crab, clams, prawns and ribs — have earned the Indonesian influencer millions of fans on TikTok.

headline: Make Soup Now for When You’re Sick Later
abstract: Come cold season, future you will be relieved by pints of carrot-leek with miso, white bean with rice and dill, and vegetable tortilla stashed in the freezer.
lead_paragraph: There’s something in the air. No, I’m not talking about the promise of scarves and plaid button-downs wafting in the breeze. I’m talking about germs.

headline: White House Directs Agencies to Account for Climate Change in Budgets
abstract: The directive is intended to embed the cost of climate change into all federal agencies. But it is not legally binding and could come with legal and logistical challenges.
lead_paragraph: A directive issued on Thursday by the Biden administration would, for the first time, have federal agencies consider the economic damage caused by climate change when deciding what kinds of vehicles, equipment and goods to buy.

headline: Tiny Memoir Contest for Students: Write a 100-Word Personal Narrative
abstract: From Oct. 4 to Nov. 1, we invite teenagers to tell a true story about a meaningful life experience in just 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Can you tell a meaningful and interesting true story from your life in just 100 words? That’s the challenge we posed to teenagers last fall with our first-ever 100-Word Personal Narrative Contest, a storytelling form popularized by Modern Love’s Tiny Love Stories series.

headline: Angus Cloud Died of Accidental Drug Overdose, Coroner Finds
abstract: Mr. Cloud, who appeared on the HBO show “Euphoria,” had ingested cocaine, methamphetamine, fentanyl and benzodiazepines, according to the coroner’s office.
lead_paragraph: The death of Angus Cloud, the 25-year-old actor who portrayed the drug dealer Fezco on the HBO show “Euphoria,” was caused by acute intoxication following an accidental overdose, according to the Alameda County Coroner’s Bureau.

headline: Do Some Men Love Ancient Rome for the Wrong Reasons?
abstract: In two new books, the historians Adrian Goldsworthy and Tom Holland portray an empire that knew how to hold back from a fight and make room for upstarts.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Empire, an enormous multiethnic state that controlled Western and Central Europe, the Near East and portions of North Africa for 500 years, has been on some people’s minds lately. Why? Perhaps it has fired the imaginations of so many sons, fathers and boyfriends because it represents a kind of antediluvian ideal of masculine potency and strength — “gladiators, legions, warfare and imperial eagles,” as one article recently put it. But while the image of this empire in the modern world is of an immutable military might, in reality the imperial system survived because it was flexible. It was far more adaptable than the flailing democracy it replaced in the first century B.C., or the modern British and French empires, which later claimed Rome as a model.

headline: Are High Rates Going to Last? Fed Officials Increasingly Think So.
abstract: Federal Reserve officials forecast higher interest rates through 2026 this week, a sign that borrowing costs are not heading back to the rock-bottom levels normal before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The era of ultralow interest rates may be over. At the very least, policymakers don’t expect the type of low borrowing costs that prevailed before the pandemic to return anytime soon.

headline: Ophelia Brings Heavy Rains From Washington, D.C., to New York City
abstract: Ophelia, now a post-tropical cyclone, could pose a risk of coastal flooding in the Northeast on Sunday, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rainfall from the remnants of Tropical Storm Ophelia may produce localized flash and urban flooding from Virginia to New Jersey through Sunday as the weather system continues to wind down, forecasters said.

headline: He Drove Into a Creek and Died. His Family Blames Google Maps.
abstract: Philip Paxson’s family said in a lawsuit that he was following Google Maps directions last year when he drove off a collapsed bridge in Hickory, N.C., plunged into a creek and drowned.
lead_paragraph: The family of a North Carolina man who drowned last year after he drove off a collapsed bridge while following Google Maps directions has sued Google for negligence, saying that the company’s failure to update its maps led directly to his death.

headline: India to Reserve One-Third of Parliamentary Seats for Women
abstract: The landmark legislation will also apply to state legislatures, but it may be years before the law comes into force.
lead_paragraph: Indian lawmakers passed landmark legislation on Thursday that would reserve one-third of all seats for women in the lower house of Parliament and in state legislatures, a move aimed at improving gender parity among lawmakers. But the new rules will not apply to next year’s national elections.

headline: Writers, Actors and Others Struggle to Pay the Rent as Strikes Continue
abstract: Film industry charities are fielding hundreds of calls a day from unemployed workers seeking financial assistance — nearly all asking for help with their rent and mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Faye Lauren, a celebrity makeup artist, loved the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, apartment she shared with two roommates for eight years. She strung fairy lights in the backyard, drank her morning coffee on the front balcony and furnished the place with West Elm pieces. But in July, when Hollywood actors called a strike, celebrity red carpet events, and, in turn, Ms. Lauren’s career, evaporated. Without income, Ms. Lauren could not pay the rent.

headline: Sophie Turner Sues Joe Jonas to Return Their Children to England
abstract: Sophie Turner accused Joe Jonas of refusing to give her their two children’s passports, weeks after the couple announced their planned divorce.
lead_paragraph: The actress Sophie Turner sued her husband, the musician Joe Jonas, on Thursday and requested that their two children be returned to England.

headline: Nearly 500,000 in U.S. Will Regain Health Insurance After State Errors
abstract: Low-income people who wrongly lost Medicaid or Children’s Health Insurance Program coverage will keep their insurance, federal officials said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 500,000 people, many of them children, will keep Medicaid and Children’s Health Insurance Program coverage after state officials discovered major errors in their procedures for reviewing program eligibility, federal officials said on Thursday.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends checking out a kooky comedy show, a medieval slugfest and a probing new documentary about the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: ‘Game Changer’When to watch: Now, on Dropout.tv, or YouTube.

headline: A Lush Novel at the Nexus of Food, Pleasure, Wealth and Catastrophe
abstract: In C Pam Zhang’s “Land of Milk and Honey,” a chef finds herself in an elite community for the superrich in the Italian Alps, one of the last places on Earth where crops still grow.
lead_paragraph: A couple of summers ago, as I drove through Oregon amid a record heat wave across the Pacific Northwest, I pulled over at a trailhead to eat a plum. Wildfires were burning, temperatures hovered around 100 degrees and the pine forest in front of me had been rendered ghostly, the edges of everything lost and faintly browned by smoke. It was a shock, then, to bite into the fruit and taste its disruptive sweetness, how fresh and pure it was in spite of the surroundings. It was the sort of thing that tears the mind and body in opposite directions — and as we face down a moment increasingly dominated by environmental crisis, this may be the ambivalent flavor of our future: sweet and bitter and full of contradiction.

headline: Prime Minister of Norway Defends Country’s Use of Fossil Fuel
abstract: Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store of Norway refused to commit to a date to discontinue the use of oil and gas.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store of Norway refused to commit to a date to discontinue the use of oil and gas.

headline: Remembering Jimmy Buffett, Beach Bum Bard
abstract: A conversation about how the musician, who died this month at 76, turned a way of life into a song — and that song back into a very profitable way of life.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Buffett, who died this month at 76, was best known for one thing: making an island-friendly country-rock concoction that millions of listeners found to be a balm. He turned that balm into big business — “Margaritaville,” the song, was his lone Top 10 hit, and Margaritaville, the business he built atop it, became a licensing juggernaut and netted countless millions in revenue.

headline: James Dolan on Owning the Knicks: ‘You’re Not Beloved Until You’re Dead’
abstract: In a series of interviews over the past five months, Mr. Dolan had eye-opening things to say about his New York sports teams and their fans.
lead_paragraph: The focus of James L. Dolan’s attention is his new Las Vegas super-arena, called the Sphere, which includes 700,000 square feet of video screens and will open with a series of mostly sold out U2 concerts next week.

headline: Booker Prize Shortlist Reflects the ‘Unease of Our Moment’
abstract: Books by Paul Harding, Jonathan Escoffery and Chetna Maroo are among six titles nominated for the prestigious literary award.
lead_paragraph: Paul Murray’s “The Bee Sting,” a tragicomedy about a family on the brink of financial ruin, and Jonathan Escoffery’s “If I Survive You,” which explores an American of Jamaican descent’s struggles with identity, are among six titles shortlisted for this year’s Booker Prize — one of the highest profile awards in literature.

headline: C.E.O. of Google Rival Describes Obstacles to Efforts to Compete
abstract: Gabriel Weinberg of the search engine DuckDuckGo was the first competitor to testify in the Justice Department’s antitrust trial against Google.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of DuckDuckGo on Thursday described Google as a monopoly that has hurt competition and consumers through its scale and command over the tech industry, in the first testimony of a rival in the federal trial of the Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit against the search giant.

headline: Two Dead and Dozens Injured as Bus Carrying High School Students Crashes
abstract: The bus was transporting a high school marching band from Long Island to a camp in Pennsylvania when it crashed on a New York highway.
lead_paragraph: Two died and dozens of others were injured, at least five critically, after a bus carrying a high school marching band from Long Island crashed on a New York highway and went down an embankment on Thursday afternoon, the authorities said. None of the students were among the dead.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Topping our list of recommendations this week is an anthology celebrating five decades of Ms. magazine and its groundbreaking coverage of feminist causes, so it’s fitting that we also recommend three books of fiction with feminist concerns at their center: Mona Awad’s “Rouge,” a dark fairy tale about the beauty industry, Margaret Meyer’s “The Witching Tide,” a historical novel inspired by an actual witch hunt, and Rachel Ingalls’s wry novella “In the Act,” about a woman who discovers the sex robot her husband keeps in the attic.

headline: Rising Separatism, and a Killing, at a Sikh Temple in Canada
abstract: Hardeep Singh Nijjar, the Sikh leader whose killing has ignited tensions between Canada and India, increased calls for an independent homeland in India.
lead_paragraph: The markers of separatism are everywhere at the temple. Dozens of yellow flags of Khalistan — a homeland that Sikh separatists want to create in the Punjab region of India — fly in and around the grounds of the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara temple near Vancouver.

headline: Alabama School Band Director Says Police Used a Taser to Stop the Music
abstract: Johnny Mims, Minor High School’s band director, was arrested during a confrontation in which he refused to stop his band from playing after their team won.
lead_paragraph: The football team of Minor High School in Adamsville, Ala., had just beaten its opponent at an away game in Birmingham last week when Johnny Mims, the school’s band director, told his musicians to play three more tunes in celebration as the crowd prepared to file out of the stadium.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Focus on China to Demonstrate Foreign Policy Credentials
abstract: The 2024 hopefuls are rolling out plans to counter Beijing, criticizing President Biden while largely sidestepping topics more divisive among Republican voters.
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential hopefuls eager to demonstrate their foreign policy credentials on the campaign trail have homed in on China, a topic that allows them to assail President Biden while focusing less on global issues more divisive with primary voters.

headline: Marvin Newman, Photographer of Sports and the Streets, Dies at 95
abstract: He captured people in shadow on Chicago sidewalks and under storefronts in wintry Coney Island. He also shot athletes like Muhammad Ali and Mickey Mantle.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Newman, a renowned photographer who brought a quirky, artistic eye to capturing shadows on a Chicago main street; people in front of shuttered storefronts on Coney Island; and athletes in competition, including Bill Mazeroski of the Pittsburgh Pirates smashing the 1960 World Series-winning home run, died on Sept. 13 at his home in Jersey City, N.J. He was 95.

headline: Bill Gates Says ‘Brute Force’ Climate Policies Won’t Work
abstract: Speaking at a live event at The Times Center in New York, the billionaire philanthropist argued for a pragmatic, technology-driven approach to global warming.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the multibillionaire founder of Microsoft, argued for a pragmatic, technology-driven approach to fighting climate change on Thursday.

headline: How Rupert Murdoch Built His Media Empire
abstract: Over seven decades, the Australian-born magnate compiled an array of news outlets, book publishers, and film and television properties into a global behemoth.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the 92-year-old media tycoon who announced his retirement on Thursday, spent the past 70 years building a global media empire that gave him influence in journalism, politics and pop culture.

headline: For Tinned Fish Obsessives, ‘Affordable Luxury’ Comes in a Can
abstract: As more grazers turn snacks into meals, canned seafood is gaining a foothold on those charcuterie boards, thanks in part to TikTok.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Robert McGinnis came across a series of TikTok videos about tinned fish featuring people holding handfuls of colorful cans, opening them and pairing them on charcuterie boards.

headline: Venezuelan Migrants Scored a Big Victory. How Will It Affect New York?
abstract: With nearly 500,000 Venezuelan migrants able to legally work, N.Y. officials were weighing the practical and political impact of a complex decision.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s decision to grant special status to Venezuelan migrants will have no greater impact than in New York City, where thousands of immigrants will soon be eligible to begin legally applying for work and eventually move out of taxpayer-funded shelters.

headline: The East Village Restaurants Where a Restaurant Critic Cut His Teeth
abstract: Living in the neighborhood in the 1980s and '90s, I was always hungry and always broke. I got pretty far on that combination.
lead_paragraph: Hi, it’s Pete Wells, restaurant critic of The Times and longtime pierogi appreciator.

headline: Designer Files New Lawsuit Against Lizzo and Her Wardrobe Manager
abstract: The singer, who already faces one lawsuit alleging a hostile work environment, has repeatedly denied wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: A former wardrobe designer who worked briefly on Lizzo’s 2023 tour before being dismissed filed a lawsuit on Thursday alleging that the tour’s wardrobe manager had created a hostile work environment that tour management and Lizzo failed to address.

headline: Manet and Degas: A Masterful Pas de Deux at the Met
abstract: Two titans of modern art — and famous frenemies — face off in New York in a show exploring their enigmatic relationship.
lead_paragraph: The Met’s galleries for 19th- and early-20th-century European paintings and sculpture are among the museum’s buzziest places. Packed, always. Why? Because we like what we know. Here, we’re in a secular world of relatable narratives — about work, play, sex, fashion — set in smoke-gray cities and landscapes as lush but tame as those of Central Park. No halos here, no hellfire, few kings or queens, pretty much no suffering or death. Or so it would seem at a glance.

headline: Inside the Manhattan Hotel That Is the New Ellis Island
abstract: City officials describe the Roosevelt Hotel, the city’s main intake center for homeless migrants, as the “new Ellis Island.” But local political leaders are also hoping to restrict who comes.
lead_paragraph: Inside a once grand but long-faded hotel in midtown Manhattan, dozens of immigrants huddle together beneath large chandeliers as they wait hours to be processed. They give their information — where they’ve come from, and their ultimate destination — and they strip down for a medical examination. They rest and hold their children tight.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the End of Race-Based Affirmative Action in College Admissions
abstract: Teenagers around the country weigh in on the Supreme Court’s June ruling.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in June to reject race-conscious admissions at colleges and universities around the nation upended decades of law and the higher education landscape. The ruling will shift the makeup of many of America’s top universities as well as the prospects of students who want to attend them.

headline: Biden Faces Competing Pressures as He Tries to Ease the Migrant Crisis
abstract: The situation provides ammunition to conservative Republicans who are vowing to shut down the government unless Congress agrees to strict new anti-immigration measures.
lead_paragraph: The demand that President Biden ease the migrant crisis threatening to overwhelm American cities came privately, from the New York governor to top White House officials. It came publicly, in angry statements from Democratic and Republican officials around the country. It came from scores of immigrant rights groups.

headline: ‘9 Kinds of Silence’ Review: A Soldier’s Battle Is Within
abstract: In Abhishek Majumdar’s tense play at 122CC Theater in Manhattan, every sound underscores what’s left unsaid after a shellshocked veteran’s homecoming.
lead_paragraph: Waves crash and dogs howl beyond concrete walls, while inside a holding cell a rotary phone trills and typewriter keys lash at a sparsely filled page. There are few moments of quiet in “9 Kinds of Silence,” directed by the playwright Abhishek Majumdar, with original music and densely layered sound design by M. Florian Staab. In this tense parable about a soldier’s homecoming that opened at 122CC Theater in Manhattan on Monday night, every sound underscores what’s left unsaid.

headline: Friday Briefing: Zelensky’s High-Stakes Washington Visit
abstract: Plus tourists buying tickets to attend an Indian wedding.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky was welcomed at the White House yesterday as President Biden faces pushback from some Republican lawmakers in Congress who oppose providing further assistance to Ukraine.

headline: Bill Gates Champions Innovation as Way to Combat Climate Change
abstract: “Are we the science people or are we the idiots?” asked Bill Gates, during a discussion about his pragmatic strategy to fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: “Are we the science people or are we the idiots?” asked Bill Gates, during a discussion about his pragmatic strategy to fighting climate change.

headline: Donald Trump Tests Pro-Life America
abstract: For the pro-life movement, persuasion is everything.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Donald Trump sent shock waves through the Republican primary when an interview with NBC’s Kristen Welker on “Meet the Press” aired in which he said that Ron DeSantis did a “terrible thing” and made a “terrible mistake” when he signed Florida’s six-week abortion ban. It’s the kind of statement that could end virtually any other Republican presidential campaign. Opposition to abortion rights, after all, is every bit as fundamental to Republican identity as support for abortion rights is to Democratic identity. Breaking with the party on that issue is the kind of heresy that no national politician can survive.

headline: Senate Confirms Army and Marine Chiefs, but Tuberville’s Blockade Drags On
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer’s move to clear the way for the confirmation of three top generals left unanswered the question of what would happen to hundreds of other military promotions.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly confirmed Gen. Randy George of the Army and Gen. Eric Smith of the Marines as the chiefs of staff of their respective services, circumventing a single senator’s blockade against senior military promotions but leaving hundreds more still in limbo.

headline: A Trap Door Hid a Cache of Narcotics at the Day Care Where a Child Died
abstract: A neighbor said that the apartment had been renovated before the home-based facility opened, and workers had installed a new floor.
lead_paragraph: Days after a 1-year-old died and three children exposed to drugs at a Bronx day care site were hospitalized, investigators uncovered a trap door under a play area that was concealing fentanyl, other narcotics and drug paraphernalia.

headline: Victor R. Fuchs, ‘Dean’ of American Health Care Economists, Dies at 99
abstract: He was among the first to offer a comprehensive explanation, and a possible solution, for the country’s rising health care costs.
lead_paragraph: Victor R. Fuchs, whose comprehensive grasp of the challenges facing the United States health care system, and eloquence in explaining those challenges to policymakers and the general public, made him what many called the “dean” of American health care economists, died on Saturday at his home on the campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 99.

headline: ‘Expend4bles’ Review: Band of Meatheads
abstract: Sylvester Stallone leads an all-star mercenary squadron composed of ’80s-to-aughts brutes in the fourth installment of this franchise.
lead_paragraph: The tone of “Expend4bles” can be summarized in a single close-up: a corpse’s severed hand flipping the bird. To its director, Scott Waugh, and all those responsible for resurrecting this dormant action franchise, the middle finger gestures toward this fourth installment’s intended style: macho, smirky and defiant. At its best, the film is all three. This all-star mercenary squadron composed of ’80s-to-aughts brutes is the cinematic equivalent to Slash’s Snakepit, a supergroup throwback to an era when men were meatheads and we in the audience merrily cheered them on.

headline: A Major Effort to Ease the Migrant Crisis
abstract: Also, Rupert Murdoch is retiring. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: After months of calls for action from fellow Democrats, President Biden late last night announced that the U.S. would grant work permits and offer temporary protection to nearly half a million Venezuelans who had already entered the U.S.

headline: Mia Mottley Calls for Financial Solutions to Transition to Clean Energy
abstract: The prime minister of Barbados discussed her country’s eagerness and limitations to develop renewable energy infrastructures with the World Bank’s president, Ajay Banga.
lead_paragraph: The prime minister of Barbados discussed her country’s eagerness and limitations to develop renewable energy infrastructures with the World Bank’s president, Ajay Banga.

headline: State Dept. Contractor Is Accused of Stealing Satellite Imagery of Africa
abstract: Court documents offer new detail on a case involving a contractor who obtained classified information, which U.S. officials said he shared with Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: A State Department contractor stole classified documents that included satellite imagery and other sensitive information about military activities in Africa, federal prosecutors said in a criminal complaint unsealed on Thursday.

headline: 1-Year-Old Girl’s Death in Brooklyn Is Investigated as a Homicide
abstract: Police came to an apartment in Crown Heights, where they found the child unresponsive. She died six days later.
lead_paragraph: A 1-year-old girl died Wednesday after what the police said was an assault at a Brooklyn apartment, and the case is being investigated as a homicide.

headline: The Fault Lines at Climate Week
abstract: There are big differences of opinion on how to get the job done.
lead_paragraph: Today was the day for The New York Times’s annual Climate Forward live event in Manhattan. David Gelles, Somini Sengupta and other Times reporters talked with some of the climate sector’s most vital newsmakers to share ideas, work through problems and answer tough questions about the threats presented by a rapidly warming planet.

headline: Why Kevin McCarthy Can’t Do His Job
abstract: How to make Newt Gingrich look good in retrospect.
lead_paragraph: The speaker of the House is the only congressional officer mentioned in the Constitution, other than a temporary Senate officer to preside when the vice president can’t. The speaker’s job isn’t defined, but surely it includes passing legislation that keeps the federal government running.

headline: A Theory of Elon Musk’s Maniacal Drive
abstract: The entrepreneur seems to see himself as a mythical hero.
