lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union significantly expanded its strike today to include every spare-parts distribution center operated by General Motors and Stellantis (the parent of Jeep and Ram). More than 5,000 workers at 38 plants across 21 states walked off the job, bringing the total number of striking U.A.W. workers to more than 18,000.

headline: Arriving Now: Fast Passenger Trains From Miami to Orlando
abstract: Brightline will make the trip in three and a half hours, with round-trip tickets starting at $158.
lead_paragraph: The fastest train in the country outside of the Northeast began service between Miami and Orlando on Friday, connecting two major cities in car-loving Florida and testing whether private passenger rail can thrive in the United States.

headline: Did Gucci Just Score the Starriest Fashion Week Front Row?
abstract: Amid the strikes in Hollywood, the fashion house lured Julia Roberts, Ryan Gosling and Jessica Chastain to Milan for Sabato De Sarno’s debut show.
lead_paragraph: At first it was hard to make out anyone, let alone some of the most famous human beings in the world. The vast hangar on the outskirts of Milan was cloaked in near total darkness. Most people couldn’t see their rain-soaked toes, let alone a star-studded front row.

headline: Former F.B.I. Spy Hunter Admits to Hiding Payments in Overseas Dealings
abstract: The official, Charles F. McGonigal, also pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate U.S. sanctions and to launder payments from a Russian oligarch in a separate case in New York.
lead_paragraph: A former top F.B.I. spy hunter pleaded guilty on Friday in Federal District Court in Washington to concealing payments he received from an Albanian-born businessman — a former intelligence agent he had helped in business dealings overseas.

headline: Capturing John Zorn at 70: One Concert Is Just a Start
abstract: The Miller Theater at Columbia University began a series of programs to celebrate this restless and eclectic musician’s milestone year.
lead_paragraph: John Zorn may have turned 70 this month, but he looks younger.

headline: Justice Kagan Calls for the Supreme Court to Adopt an Ethics Code
abstract: In remarks at Notre Dame, the justice also discussed ideological divisions at the court, the role of precedent and a sharp exchange in the recent student loans case.
lead_paragraph: Justice Elena Kagan said on Friday that the Supreme Court should adopt a code of ethics, saying that “it would be a good thing for the court to do that.”

headline: Mother Who Gave Abortion Pills to Teen Daughter Gets 2 Years in Prison
abstract: Jessica Burgess had pleaded guilty to violating Nebraska’s abortion law. Her daughter, who was 17 when she ended her late-term pregnancy last year, was sentenced in July to 90 days in jail.
lead_paragraph: A Nebraska woman who acquired abortion pills that her teenage daughter used to end her pregnancy last year was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison.

headline: What We Lose When We Loosen Dress Codes
abstract: Allowing senators to wear what they please on the Senate floor may seem like liberation, but abandoning the dress code could wind up symbolizing the failure to achieve consensus.
lead_paragraph: Responses to the Senate majority leader Chuck Schumer’s new relaxation of Senate dress codes have so far fallen along partisan lines: Republicans have been deploring it as a lapse in decorum and order. “Most if not all Republican senators think we ought to dress up to go to work,” Mitch McConnell said. Mitt Romney called it “a terrible choice,” and from the House, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene pronounced the change “disgraceful.”

headline: With House Hurtling Toward a Shutdown, Gaetz Is Leading the Resistance
abstract: The Florida Republican, who has styled himself as Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s chief tormentor, is leading the opposition to a measure to keep the government open.
lead_paragraph: At a closed-door meeting with Republicans in the basement of the Capitol on Wednesday night, Speaker Kevin McCarthy pitched what he thought could finally be a breakthrough in a spending dispute with right-wing rebels that had left the House in a state of paralysis, staring down a disastrous shutdown with no way to move forward.

headline: Biden Creates Federal Office of Gun Violence Prevention
abstract: The office will be led by Vice President Kamala Harris, who pursued gun safety measures when she was California’s top prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday announced a new office dedicated to gun violence prevention, his latest effort to combat a growing national crisis through executive action instead of the more sweeping reforms that would require congressional approval.

headline: Gold, an Investment for Some, Is a Portable Vehicle for Graft
abstract: Prosecutors say Senator Robert Menendez had a cache of ill-gotten ingots and a sudden interest in the price of the precious metal.
lead_paragraph: Of all the details in the federal indictment of Senator Robert Menendez, one of the most eye-popping may be the assertion that a sizable chunk of the graft he is charged with collecting came in the form of gold bars.

headline: Love, by Another Name
abstract: Robert Charlton delivers a winsome debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Robert Charlton’s first published crossword anywhere, not just in The New York Times; springing a tough grid like this on us out of the blue feels auspicious to me. I tend to think of doubled triple stacks as the equivalent of a black diamond ski slope, a challenge that requires experience in both solver and constructor. Not in this case! All of these excellent span entries sandwich a juicy clue set, with hardly a bit of cheap filler.

headline: Quotation of the Day: India’s ‘Lake Man’ Uses Ancient Ways to Ease a Water Crisis
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “You can find alternatives to milk, but what will you do without water?”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 23, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the timeline of Rupert Murdoch’s career misstated how much the Walt Disney Company paid to acquire most of 21st Century Fox’s assets in 2019. It was $71.3 billion, not $71.3 million.

headline: How a Storied National Airline Became Reviled in Its Own Country
abstract: A string of scandals has left Qantas Airways, which calls itself “the spirit of Australia,” near the bottom of public opinion at home.
lead_paragraph: Barely three years after its entire fleet was grounded, Qantas Airways has never been more profitable. But as Australia’s national airline has emerged stronger from the pandemic, it has alienated its most important constituency: Australians.

headline: Progress in Hollywood Writers’ Strike Negotiations, but No Deal Yet
abstract: A third straight day of bargaining between the studios and the union ended without an agreement. Talks continued on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A third straight day of marathon negotiations between Hollywood studios and striking screenwriters ended on Friday night without a deal. But the sides made substantial progress, according to three people briefed on the talks.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Knicks Hardly Interested Me. The Owner Was Another Story.
abstract: A reporter who writes about New York’s personalities set her sights on James L. Dolan, whom everyone thinks they know.
lead_paragraph: After more than 25 years of living in New York City, I attended my first New York Knicks game in June. It was Game 5 of the second round of the N.B.A. playoffs, against the Miami Heat, with exciting action that saw the Knicks storm ahead in the second half and cling to the lead to win 112-103.

headline: ‘Victoria’s Secret Karen’ Video: Lawsuits Show What Viewers Didn’t See
abstract: Video of the white woman taken by a Black shopper at a New Jersey mall laid bare the power of online outrage.
lead_paragraph: It began with a Covid-era tussle over social distancing at a New Jersey shopping mall known for its high-end stores.

headline: How an Animal Rescuer and Cat Cafe Owner Spends Her Sundays
abstract: On top of caring for dozens of adoptable cats, Anne Levin once raised an orphaned baby subway rat. She named him Alexander Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: Anne Levin never knows what Sunday will bring. When you’re the executive director of the Brooklyn Bridge Animal Welfare Coalition — which provides animal rescuers with veterinary, foster and adoptive support — and a co-founder of its affiliated cat cafe, anything’s possible.

headline: Does Robert Menendez Have Enough Teflon to Survive Again?
abstract: Senator Menendez, who has defeated prosecutors and political challengers, faces his sternest test yet in his federal indictment in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In a state long attuned to the drumbeat of political corruption — salacious charges, furious denials, explosive trials — Senator Robert Menendez has often registered as the quintessential New Jersey politician.

headline: Gold Bullion and Halal Meat: Inside the Menendez Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors have accused Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his wife, Nadine, of accepting bribes in exchange for official actions by Mr. Menendez.
lead_paragraph: It was January 2018, and Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey had just won a huge legal victory. His trial on federal bribery charges had ended in a hung jury, and the U.S. Justice Department had announced that it would not seek a new trial. He was free to walk with no criminal conviction, ready to take on another campaign for re-election.

headline: Where Fashion Knows No Bounds
abstract: During London Fashion Week, the streets become a laboratory for experiments in getting dressed.
lead_paragraph: Some people in the fashion industry think that London Fashion Week has become less exciting than its counterparts. But you have to wonder if those people pay attention to the streets.

headline: The Great Gucci Reset Is Here
abstract: Sabato De Sarno’s first collection arrives. Think of it as a breeze, rather than a wind, of change.
lead_paragraph: Sabato De Sarno, the designer who was essentially unknown outside the industry until he was handed the keys to the $10 billion Gucci kingdom earlier this year and tasked with reinventing a brand that had already been reinvented twice before — once by Tom Ford, as a uniform for sultry power players and then again by Alessandro Michele as a big-tent haven for fashion freakazoids high and low — called his first collection “Ancora.”

headline: In Marseille, Francis Urges Europe to Heed the Plight of Migrants
abstract: Pope Francis said the migrant route through the Mediterranean had become a “graveyard of dignity.”
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of faithful were drawn on Saturday to a soccer stadium in the south of France, not for a match, but for a Mass presided over by Pope Francis, who was on the second day of a whirlwind trip to the port city of Marseille.

headline: Maria Bamford Is Particular About What You Put in the Little Free Library
abstract: “There is the danger of being Dan Browned,” said the comedian and author of “Sure, I’ll Join Your Cult.” Debtors Anonymous, coffee-shop chitchat and a well-timed pool gag help her stay afloat.
lead_paragraph: Money, prestige and fame were deciding factors when the comedian Maria Bamford first considered writing about herself. So was having an authority figure ask her to do something. “Simon & Schuster said, ‘We’ll pay you $150,000,’” she recalled. “I said, ‘Wow, this is a dream I didn’t even know I had coming.’”

headline: Otherworldly Horrors Envelop a Scripted Ghost-Hunting Reality TV Show
abstract: In Nora Fussner’s new novel, the jaded producers of “Searching For … the Invisible World” are pulled into a haunted story they initially refuse to believe.
lead_paragraph: Ghost stories often start with a bump in the night, a figure in a mirror, a disembodied voice whispering from the void. But Nora Fussner’s thought-provoking debut novel, “The Invisible World,” opens with a different kind of bang: the slam of a van door as the crew of a struggling supernatural reality show pulls up to a farmhouse to shoot their newest episode.

headline: John Cage Shock: When Japan Fell for Cage and Vice Versa
abstract: After a 1962 visit, a mutual love affair began between the composer and the country’s musicians. A new series at the Japan Society explores this relationship.
lead_paragraph: About 30 miles south of Tokyo is the city of Kamakura, where the American composer John Cage was taken soon after arriving on his first visit to Japan, in 1962.

headline: Chinese Navy Confronts Philippine Ship in Disputed Waters
abstract: Chinese vessels have been challenging other vessels over a contested part of the West Philippine Sea.
lead_paragraph: Chinese vessels have been challenging other vessels over a contested part of the West Philippine Sea.

headline: The Beauty of a Silent Walk
abstract: No talking. No podcasts. No music. Just some time alone with your thoughts.
lead_paragraph: In a TikTok video that has now amassed nearly half a million views, the influencer Mady Maio describes taking a walk. But not just any walk: a silent one.

headline: Warriors Who Seek Immortal Fame and Find It, in Epic Poetry
abstract: Emily Wilson’s translation of the “Iliad” brings Homer’s great war story to rousing new life.
lead_paragraph: “War is a task for men,” the Trojan prince Hector says to his wife, Andromache, in Emily Wilson’s propulsive new translation of Homer’s “Iliad.” “For every man/born here in Troy, but most especially, me.”

headline: A Grisly Teenage Murder and the Ethics of True Crime
abstract: In Eliza Clark’s novel “Penance,” a 16-year-old becomes more fascinating in death than she was in life.
lead_paragraph: “Penance,” Eliza Clark’s sophomore novel, begins with a fictional but realistic disclaimer: The following book is a work of nonfiction written by the English journalist Alec Z. Carelli and examining the grisly 2016 murder of a North Yorkshire teenager. “Shortly after publication, several of Carelli’s interviewees publicly accused Carelli of misrepresenting and even fabricating some of the content of their interviews,” the text reads; the author also illegally acquired therapeutic writing by two of the incarcerated perpetrators. We enter this book already aware that our narrator is an untrustworthy one. But as we whip out our imaginary magnifying glasses, distracted by our eagerness to play sleuth and look for the lies in Carelli’s story, Clark shrewdly turns her own lens onto us, onto our obsession with true crime and our complicity in the industry it has spawned.

headline: The Mystery of My Mother’s Prayer Book
abstract: A precious object finds its way home.
lead_paragraph: It started with an email. The subject line: “Sylvia Kanner’s Siddur.” Kanner was my late mother’s maiden name. Siddur is the Hebrew word for prayer book. I was, to say the least, intrigued.

headline: Arsenic Preserved the Animals, but Killed the Museum
abstract: A popular taxidermy exhibit in Sioux Falls, S.D., was closed after the toxic substance was discovered laced throughout the specimens. Many lament the loss of the “works of art.”
lead_paragraph: Usually, you go to the zoo to look at live animals. But at the Great Plains Zoo in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, people also went to see the dead ones.

headline: Blasting Bullhorns and Water Cannons, Chinese Ships Wall Off the Sea
abstract: The world’s most brazen maritime militarization is gaining muscle in waters through which one-third of global ocean trade passes.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese military base on Mischief Reef, off the Philippine island of Palawan, loomed in front of our boat, obvious even in the predawn dark.

headline: Netflix Prepares to Send Its Final Red Envelope
abstract: The company’s DVD subscription service is ending this month, bringing to a close an origin story that ultimately upended the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: In a nondescript office park minutes from Disneyland sits a nondescript warehouse. Inside this nameless, faceless building, an era is ending.

headline: U.S. Army Hospital in Germany Is Treating Americans Hurt Fighting in Ukraine
abstract: The Army’s Landstuhl Regional Medical Center has quietly started admitting Ukrainian Army soldiers who were wounded in combat, most of them American volunteers.
lead_paragraph: A group of Ukrainian Army soldiers pierced by Russian grenades and mortar shells arrived at a hospital recently in need of surgery. It would have been a familiar scene from the bloody war grinding on in Ukraine, except for two crucial differences: Most of the wounded soldiers were American, and so was the hospital — the U.S. Army’s flagship medical center in Germany.

headline: Should We Oust Our Co-op Managing Agent and Find Another?
abstract: In co-ops, building-wide issues are the responsibility of the board to address and remediate, but a good managing agent is critical.
lead_paragraph: Q. I live in a large co-op building in the West Village. Our central air-conditioning has been spotty, and on 22 different days this summer, building management shut it off. We’d get very little notice — one day, management gave us a 30-minute warning. Then they shut the air-conditioning off for good in early September because of damage to the cooling equipment, despite the high heat and humidity in the days that followed. Is there a way to hire a new management company, or are there other actions that we can take? We pay a high monthly maintenance fee and this has been very frustrating.

headline: An Ohio Town Struggles Between Biden’s Clean Energy Agenda and Union Support
abstract: Contract talks at an electric vehicle battery plant in Lordstown could have even more of an impact than the autoworkers’ strike on the labor standards of the emerging electric-vehicle industry.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of a shuttered General Motors plant in Lordstown, Ohio, far from the United Automobile Workers’ picket lines, the U.A.W. and the management of an electric vehicle battery plant are locked in a wholly different conflict.

headline: On ‘Golden Bachelor,’ Looking for Love and a Pickleball Partner
abstract: The latest “Bachelor” spinoff stars singles who are 60 and older, a largely ignored demographic in the ever-growing world of dating shows.
lead_paragraph: Drivers in Los Angeles heading north on La Cienega Boulevard these days might notice a bronzed gentleman smiling down at them from billboards poised on either side of the street.

headline: Ancient Arrow Is Among Artifacts to Emerge From Norway’s Melting Ice
abstract: As the earth warms, glacial archaeologists are in a race against time to preserve objects before they are destroyed by the elements. Recent field work yielded a surprisingly intact 3,000-year-old arrow.
lead_paragraph: Espen Finstad was trudging through mud in the Jotunheimen mountains of eastern Norway this month when he happened upon a wooden arrow, bound with a pointed tip made of quartzite. Complete with feathers, it was so well-preserved that it looked as if it could have been lost just recently.

headline: Europe Made a Bold Pledge of Ammunition for Ukraine. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: After 30 years of atrophy, experts say, Europe’s shrunken military industry will struggle to provide the Ukrainians with a million artillery shells by March.
lead_paragraph: The pledge last March sounded as catchy as it was ambitious: European Union states would deliver a million rounds of 155-millimeter ammunition to Ukraine within a year.

headline: The Wrecking-Ball Caucus: How the Far Right Brought Washington to Its Knees
abstract: Right-wing Republicans who represent a minority in their party and in Congress have succeeded in sowing mass dysfunction, spoiling for a shutdown, an impeachment and a House coup.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to his view of the United States government, Representative Bob Good, a right-wing Republican who represents a Virginia district that was once the domain of Thomas Jefferson, doesn’t mince words.

headline: Tyson and Perdue Are Facing Child Labor Investigations
abstract: The Labor Department has opened inquiries into whether migrant children were working inside slaughterhouses owned by the poultry-processing giants.
lead_paragraph: Tyson Foods and Perdue Farms, which together produce a third of the poultry sold in the United States, are under federal investigation into whether they relied on migrant children to clean slaughterhouses, some of the most dangerous work in the country.

headline: Cassidy Hutchinson Reappears. She Has More Trump Stories to Tell.
abstract: “I would like not to be a hermit,” the former White House aide says upon the publication of a memoir about her journey down a political rabbit hole.
lead_paragraph: Cassidy Hutchinson, now 26, dropped out of sight last year after she testified in damning detail in a nationally televised committee hearing about President Donald J. Trump’s actions during and after the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021. Facing blistering social media attacks from Mr. Trump and threats from his supporters, she retreated from Washington and cut off contacts with her former White House world.

headline: Fears and Chaos Grow in Nagorno-Karabakh After Takeover
abstract: With food shortages and blackouts, rumors of revenge-taking abound — and are flatly denied by the Azerbaijani authorities.
lead_paragraph: Along the serpentine highway linking Armenia with Nagorno-Karabakh, a breakaway Armenian enclave, Norik Grigoryan strained to catch a glimpse of his village just a few miles away. His wife and son are stuck there, he said, after Azerbaijan reclaimed the region this week in a swift military operation.

headline: In Mississippi, a Win for Jackson Residents Battling State Control
abstract: A court says the State Legislature cannot add outside judges to Jackson’s courts, part of a larger battle over efforts to create state-run police and courts in the capitol.
lead_paragraph: When Mississippi’s mostly white and Republican-controlled State Legislature voted last spring to add a state-run police force and court system atop the existing ones in the state’s mostly Black, Democratic-run capital, Jackson, some residents went to court to fight what they called an assault on their right to self-government.

headline: TV Networks’ Last Best Hope: Boomers
abstract: Viewers have fled prime-time lineups for streaming outlets, with one notable exception: people over 60.
lead_paragraph: This coming week, as the network fall television season gets underway, ABC will begin airing “The Golden Bachelor,” a spinoff of “The Bachelor” that centers on an offbeat twist: The main contestant is a 72-year-old man, and the 22 women vying for his affection range in age from 60 to 75.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Sept. 16-22
abstract: A certain monomania, the No. 2 word in this week’s list, can help get you to the top in this game.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: Libya’s ‘City of Poets’ Pays a Heavy Price in Floods
abstract: Derna, which lost entire neighborhoods and thousands of residents in the deluge, has a history as a cultural and intellectual hub as well as a rebellious streak.
lead_paragraph: In the days after much of the coastal city of Derna, Libya, was washed away by devastating floods, Mahbuba Khalifa wrote a poem to honor her hometown, known by Libyans as the “city of poets.”

headline: This American Life: Ends of the Earth
abstract: An exploration of the very upper limits of what you do for someone you love.
lead_paragraph: An exploration of the very upper limits of what you do for someone you love. This is a rerun of an episode that first aired in September 2022.

headline: Ukraine Targets Crimea for Second Day in a Row, Russia Says
abstract: Russian-installed authorities in the occupied peninsula said debris from a downed rocket fell in the Sevastopol bay, where Moscow’s Black Sea Fleet is based.
lead_paragraph: The Russian-installed authorities in occupied Crimea said Ukrainian forces targeted the peninsula with another air attack on Saturday, the second in two days as Kyiv increasingly takes aim at the region in an effort to disrupt Moscow’s military operations.

headline: Trudeau Says of Canada’s Political Mood, ‘People Are Mad’
abstract: During a visit to The New York Times, the prime minister shared thoughts on his explosive allegation against India as well as general anxiety by the public.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the end of his visit to New York this week to attend the United Nations General Assembly, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stopped by The New York Times for a meeting with editors and reporters hosted by A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher.

headline: Farewell Forever to Netflix DVDs
abstract: The movies we watch can serve as place holders for a cache of memories, who we were and how we felt at particular moments in time.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Netflix is shutting down its mail-order DVD service. Customers who still receive physical DVDs can hold on to the ones they have. “Please enjoy your final shipments for as long as you like!” the company wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter. I misread this as “Please enjoy your final shipments for as long as you live!,” a chirpy and morbid send-off, conjuring images of a devoted Luddite breathing his last in a room littered with faded red envelopes and dusty remote controls.

headline: The U.S. Is Pulling Back From China. How Far Is Too Far?
abstract: The backlash against trade with the Chinese should not cause America to retreat from the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans, even once-ardent proponents of globalization, have soured on trade with China. But there is a growing danger that as the United States tries to address its difficulties with China, it will pull back too far, severing economic ties that benefit American families and contribute to global peace and prosperity.

headline: The Young Men of the Crick
abstract: Before the fall of the self-proclaimed prophet Warren Jeffs, many teenage boys were cast out of the Crick, as had been the custom for many generations.
lead_paragraph: Several years into photographing the unorthodox residential architecture of members of the F.L.D.S. along the Arizona-Utah border, I crossed paths with an 18-year-old former F.L.D.S. member named Jobee Cooke.

headline: We’re Teaching Music to Kids All Wrong
abstract: The problem isn’t getting instruments into students’ hands. It’s keeping them there.
lead_paragraph: Each fall, as school starts up again, music educators witness a familiar ritual: Eager first-time students squeak on a clarinet, suppress giggles at the noises coming from the tubas and zealously hit a bass drum a little too hard. It’s a moment characterized by excitement, enthusiasm and the anticipation of new beginnings — which is why it’s so disheartening to know that many of those kids will eventually quit their instruments.

headline: Caregiving for the Elderly: The Stresses and the Challenges
abstract: Readers react to an Opinion article about the lack of support for caregivers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Thoreau Heard in the Song of the Crickets
abstract: The late summer song in the grass has a message for us.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in August and well into the fall here in New England, the crickets take over the night, their song a chiming of little bells or a rhythmic ripple of falling water. There has always been folklore to tell us what that song means. In ancient Greece, Aesop took it to be a sign of careless joy. In China it still portends wisdom and good fortune. In Germany it may warn of danger.

headline: The Permanent Migration Crisis
abstract: What’s changed for formerly welcoming cities are the sheer numbers involved.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday the Biden administration announced that it will offer work permits and deportation protections to over 400,000 Venezuelans who have arrived in the United States since 2021. On paper this is a humanitarian gesture, a recognition of the miseries of life under the Maduro dictatorship. In political practice it’s a flailing attempt to respond to a sudden rise in anti-immigration sentiment in blue cities, particularly New York, as the surge of migrants overwhelms social services and shelters.

headline: An Ambitious Antiracism Center Scales Back Amid Allegations of Poor Management
abstract: Ibram X. Kendi, the center’s leader who has become a flashpoint of national controversy, faces an inquiry into complaints from staff members.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of George Floyd’s murder in May 2020, protests, looting, and anger were boiling up in the streets of Boston, a city that has played host to both abolitionists and vicious race riots. At Boston University, Black students demanded action to address campus racism.

headline: A Beach Read and a Book Purge
abstract: Answering reader mail with a recommended crime series and a book about architecture.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Are Fossil Fuels the Next Cigarettes?
abstract: California’s lawsuit against oil giants mirrors a legal strategy used in the 1990s against the tobacco industry.
lead_paragraph: California is taking some of the world’s biggest energy companies, including Shell, Exxon Mobil and Chevron, to court, accusing them of concealing the damage caused by fossil fuels on the state for more than half a century. The state’s lawsuit is the most significant attempt to take on Big Oil over its role in climate change, as the energy majors report bumper profits and oil nears $100 a barrel.

headline: The Joys of Spite Exercising
abstract: How I got in the best shape of my life.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday morning, I have new nemeses. I never know these people’s names, and I barely look at their faces. I couldn’t pick them out of a lineup. But I have my eyes fixed on their treadmills to make sure they’re not going faster than I am. If the pace is 7.3 miles per hour, I’ll kick my speed up to 7.4. If they’re going so fast that I can’t possibly get there, I’m furious. If they’re going much slower than I am, that’s irritating, too; I want realistic competitors.

headline: The Internet Is About to Get Much Worse
abstract: Why the development of artificial intelligence might result in greater pollution of our digital public spaces.
lead_paragraph: Greg Marston, a British voice actor, recently came across “Connor” online — an A.I.-generated clone of his voice, trained on a recording Mr. Marston had made in 2003. It was his voice uttering things he had never said.

headline: In Hospitals, Viruses Are Everywhere. Masks Are Not.
abstract: Amid an uptick in Covid infections, administrators, staff and patients are divided over the need for masks in health care settings.
lead_paragraph: Liv Grace came down with respiratory infections three times over the course of four months. Each occurred after a visit to a medical provider in the Bay Area.

headline: Smithsonian’s Latino Museum Faces Political Winds Before a Brick Is Laid
abstract: Partisan battles over America’s past, and divisions among Latinos, are affecting this new institution set to be built on the National Mall.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Latino, slated to rise on the National Mall in Washington, is meant to give a prominent presence to the story of America’s largest minority group. But the institution has already been caught up in the broader partisan battles over American history, before a single brick has been laid.

headline: The Lessons of the Crime Wave That Never Was
abstract: Exploring Philadelphia’s child lifers as part of a new Times series.
lead_paragraph: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]

headline: What Republicans Say (and Don’t Say) About the Auto Workers’ Strike
abstract: Their responses obscure the nature of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: It has been interesting to watch the response of Republicans to the United Auto Workers strike against the Big Three American car manufacturers: General Motors, Ford and Stellantis (formerly Chrysler).

headline: For Egypt, Menendez Was Key to Access to Billions in U.S. Aid
abstract: When the annual allotment of up to $1.3 billion faltered even a sliver, Egypt found an ally in Senator Robert J. Menendez, who on Friday was indicted on bribery charges tied to Egypt.
lead_paragraph: After decades as one of the world’s largest recipients of United States foreign aid, the Egyptian government was nervous about how long the largess would continue at that level. But when the United States cut a sliver of the aid in 2017 over Egypt’s grim human rights record, stunning Cairo, Egyptian officials found an ally in Senator Robert J. Menendez of New Jersey.

headline: Buddy Teevens, Pioneering Dartmouth Football Coach, Dies at 66
abstract: He took the extraordinary step of banning tackling during all practices, which reduced concussions at a time when brain trauma in football had become a crisis.
lead_paragraph: Buddy Teevens, who had more victories than any coach in Dartmouth College football history, and who became a nationally recognized innovator in player safety when he eliminated tackling during practices to limit the incidence of concussions, died on Tuesday in Boston. He was 66.

headline: Two Hooded Gunmen, a Silver Getaway Car and a Slain Sikh Leader
abstract: Three witnesses who said they saw the killers of Hardeep Singh Nijjar, the Sikh leader at the center of a diplomatic dispute between Canada and India, described the scene.
lead_paragraph: The Sikh temple leader wanted as a terrorist by India walked toward his pickup truck late one Sunday last June after a long day at his place of worship. He and an associate discussed some upcoming programs while making their way across the large parking lot behind the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara temple near Vancouver.

headline: Cumin and Cashew Yogurt Rice to Kick Off Fall
abstract: Creamy and tangy from yogurt, crunchy from cashews and warming from cumin and ghee, Priya Krishna’s new 10-minute recipe soothes and satisfies.
lead_paragraph: Here we are — the first day of fall. It’s an exciting time for cooking (Apples! Pumpkins! Gourds, both decorative and edible!), and we’ll be diving into those recipes headfirst the way a kid does into a pile of leaves. But let’s start the season off with something simple and soothing, with a touch of warming spices and toasted, nutty crunch. Let’s kick off fall with cumin and cashew yogurt rice (above).

headline: What Really Happened at the Biden-Netanyahu Meeting
abstract: With age comes wisdom.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks there has been a lot of discussion about Joe Biden’s age. He’s old. But you know what comes with age besides a slower gait and forgetting words? Wisdom — in particular how to handle a high-stakes diplomatic encounter without blowing things up (or blowing things up before you want them to blow up). And that’s what I think I saw at the face-to-face meeting between Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday in New York.

headline: Has Coffee Really Ousted Tea as the U.K.’s Favorite Hot Drink?
abstract: Recent studies suggest coffee has stolen Britons’ hearts. But for cafe patrons in a city that hosts some of the nation’s oldest coffeehouses, it’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: “Tea has my heart,” Liz Coleman explained as she sank into a chair under the gold-painted ceilings of the Grand Café in Oxford, England. “But I can’t live without coffee.”

headline: Tropical Storm Ophelia Hits the North Carolina Coast
abstract: Coastal areas in North Carolina experienced heavy rain and nearly hurricane-force winds as Tropical Storm Ophelia made landfall. The storm was expected to weaken while turning north toward other states.
lead_paragraph: Coastal areas in North Carolina experienced heavy rain and nearly hurricane-force winds as Tropical Storm Ophelia made landfall. The storm was expected to weaken while turning north toward other states.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Flirts With the Libertarian Party
abstract: Mr. Kennedy sat down with the party’s chair in July, a previously undisclosed meeting, as Democrats fret about a third party bid.
lead_paragraph: For months, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has said he plans to continue his long-shot challenge against President Biden in the Democratic primary rather than dropping out to launch a third-party bid.

headline: U.S. Provided Canada With Intelligence on Killing of Sikh Leader
abstract: American intelligence gave assistance, but communications intercepted by Canada were more definitive in linking India to the killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar.
lead_paragraph: American spy agencies provided information to Ottawa after the killing of a Sikh separatist leader in the Vancouver area, but Canada developed the most definitive intelligence that led it to accuse India of orchestrating the plot, according to Western allied officials.

headline: Dick Clark, Iowan Who Walked 1,300 Miles for a Senate Seat, Dies at 95
abstract: After his unlikely win, in 1972, he spent his single term pushing for a more liberal foreign policy, particularly toward Africa.
lead_paragraph: Dick Clark, a long-shot Senate candidate who won his race with a 1,300-mile trek around Iowa, then used his single term on Capitol Hill to push United States foreign policy to the left in the aftermath of the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 95.

headline: Union Deal With Ford Could Put Pressure on Other 2 Detroit Automakers
abstract: Talks continued on Saturday with all three companies, a day after the U.A.W. expanded its strike at G.M. and Stellantis.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit automakers and the United Automobile Workers continued to negotiate on Saturday, company representatives said, a day after the union expanded strikes in a way that could curtail the supply of spare parts for vehicles made by General Motors and Stellantis, which owns Jeep and Ram.

headline: For Migrants in New York Shelters, 60-Day Limit Creates More Confusion
abstract: The city began notifying adult migrants in July that they would soon have to reapply in order to stay in shelters. For some who have reached the deadline, the future remains uncertain.
lead_paragraph: New York City is implementing new rules in its homeless shelters in what officials said was an effort to reduce crowding as thousands of migrants continue to arrive from the southern border.

headline: Fugitive Convicted of Attempted Murder Is Captured After 32 Years
abstract: Greg Lawson, 63, of Louisiana, had been living in the Mexican state of Oaxaca under a stolen identity, officials said. He was arrested and extradited this week.
lead_paragraph: A Louisiana man convicted of attempted murder was returned to the United States this week after hiding in Mexico for more than 30 years, the F.B.I. announced on Wednesday.

headline: Rebrandings
abstract: Joel Fagliano and Christina Iverson’s puzzle needs a marketing department. You’re all hired!
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Saltwater in the Mississippi Threatens Water Supply in New Orleans
abstract: Extreme heat and low rainfall in the Midwest this summer caused the river level to plummet, making it vulnerable to a saltwater “wedge” from the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Drought-like conditions in the Midwest over the summer have created a growing water problem in the New Orleans area this fall.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tea Is in Britain’s Soul, but Is Coffee Filling More of Its Cups?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Tea has my heart. But I can’t live without coffee.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about Ire­land’s budget surplus misstated the number of inpatient beds in the national children’s hospital in Dub­lin. The hospital, which is under construction, is expected to have 380 beds, not 3,000.

headline: A NASA Spacecraft Comes Home With an Asteroid Gift for Earth
abstract: The seven-year Osiris-Rex mission ended on Sunday with the return of regolith from the asteroid Bennu, which might hold clues about the origins of our solar system and life.
lead_paragraph: A brown-and-white capsule that spent the last seven years swooping through the solar system — and sojourning at an asteroid — has finally come home. And it has brought a cosmic souvenir: a cache of space rock that scientists are hungry to get their hands on.

headline: As the Number of Women in the N.F.L. Expands, So Does This Group Text
abstract: Pro football has seen an influx of women hired as scouts and assistant coaches in the past decade. They have formed their own support systems.
lead_paragraph: A decade before Catherine Raîche became the current highest-ranking female executive with an N.F.L. team, she was a scout for the Canadian Football League.

headline: Where Did All the Dark-Suited Japanese Businessmen Go?
abstract: Under “Cool Biz,” salarymen and government workers don short-sleeved shirts in the summer as offices are kept above 82 degrees Fahrenheit to save energy.
lead_paragraph: It was the tail end of another long, hot Tokyo summer, and salarymen across the city were looking at their wardrobes with dread.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘I Was Wandering Through Greenwich Village on a Spring Day’
abstract: Glances over the shoulder, a Central Park proposal and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Inside the Unfounded Claim That DeSantis Abused Guantánamo Detainees
abstract: A former prisoner’s story of mistreatment at the hands of Ron DeSantis made headlines. But The New York Times found no evidence to back it up.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year ago, as Ron DeSantis’s political stock was rising, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee came forward with a stunning claim: Before he was Florida’s governor, as a young Navy lawyer, Mr. DeSantis had taken part in a forced feeding of a hunger striker at the notorious American prison, and laughed as he did so.

headline: A ‘Candid’ View of Our Changing Language
abstract: A word originally “glowing, white or pure” has settled into a figurative meaning.
lead_paragraph: In January, the New York Times reporter Emily Anthes wrote about a group of scientists who set out to learn how human activity has changed the likelihood of interspecies encounters. Using more than 2,000 wildlife cameras, they found that wild animals of different species were more likely to interact in “human-altered” landscapes, like farms. The headline that accompanied the article — “Snarl, You’re on Candid Camera” — was a play on the famous line uttered at the end of every segment of the TV show “Candid Camera”: “Smile, you’re on candid camera.”

headline: A Happy Himalayan Kingdom Is Driving Its New York City Neighbors Nuts
abstract: An extraordinarily loud air-conditioner atop the Kingdom of Bhutan’s permanent mission to the United Nations has plagued a 43rd Street apartment building for years.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, the return of the United Nations General Assembly to the east side of Manhattan is greeted as a sort of annual plague: Traffic is a nightmare. Protests of varying intensity spring up. Foreign diplomats, who spend the year parking haphazardly and declining to pay the resulting tickets, are suddenly everywhere.

headline: A Day Care Death and the Dilemma Over How to Crack Down on Drugs
abstract: Fentanyl use is increasingly out in the open, and increasingly fatal. But New Yorkers are divided over what to do: decriminalize it or make more arrests.
lead_paragraph: A few blocks away from where a 1-year-old boy died, possibly from fentanyl poisoning at his Bronx day care this month, an open-air drug market persists along a trash-strewn underpass.

headline: The Mother of ‘Eclectic’ Interior Design
abstract: OK, she didn’t invent it, and she doesn’t like the word “eclectic.” But after almost 30 years in business, the designer Kelly Wearstler has remained a celebrity in an often faceless field.
lead_paragraph: If you had suddenly been blindfolded and transported to Dahlia, a cocktail lounge that opened in May at the Downtown Proper hotel in Los Angeles, you might have asked yourself: Where in the world am I?

headline: Four Takeaways From the Robert Menendez Indictment
abstract: The New Jersey senator, his wife and three businessmen have been accused of conducting a range of corrupt schemes in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: In a 39-page indictment, federal prosecutors on Friday accused Robert Menendez, the powerful New Jersey senator and Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, of accepting bribes that included a luxury car, expensive exercise machines, mortgage payments, bars of gold bullion and more than $500,000 in cash.

headline: Who Scored a Perfect 10 at Milan Fashion Week?
abstract: Bottega Veneta and Diesel take some winning risks; Versace and Moschino go spelunking in the archives.
lead_paragraph: “Judging is an instinct.” “You’re already giving a score to this look in your mind, just express it.” So droned the Voice of God at the Sunnei show over the weekend as Milan Fashion Week drew to a close. Well, who doesn’t know truth when they hear it?

headline: Kerry Washington Goes Deep
abstract: In her memoir, “Thicker Than Water,” the famously private “Scandal” star opens up about the family secret that made her question whether she was playing the lead role in her own life.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Washington’s true colors came out over a pink cardboard box of croissants.

headline: They Want to Be K-Pop Stars. But They Won’t Hide Who They Are.
abstract: In conservative South Korea, few L.G.B.T.Q. entertainers have ever come out. The young members of QI.X don’t see the point of staying in.
lead_paragraph: At a bar in Euljiro, one of Seoul’s up-and-coming hip neighborhoods, two voices intertwined in a duet. One was high-pitched, the other an octave lower.

headline: Incarcerated for Life, an Inmate Is Left Behind by Prison Reforms
abstract: Bonnie Erwin, a disabled Black inmate who has served 39 years, fell just outside the reach of a recent law’s “compassionate release.” His former lawyer became a Republican congressman who voted against it.
lead_paragraph: Federal inmate number 14289-077 is baffled whenever the television in his Texas prison blares out assertions from supporters of Donald Trump that the former president has been victimized by a two-tiered system of justice.

headline: Books About Elites That Elites Will Probably Enjoy
abstract: The Substack pundit Fredrik deBoer and the political scientist Yascha Mounk feel that liberal ideologues and “woke” pretenders have marred American life.
lead_paragraph: The prophet of our moment, it becomes clearer by the day, was the great Supreme Court justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., who in his classic dissent in Abrams v. United States, written in 1919 during the peak of the first Red Scare, argued that free speech protections should be extended even to anarchists and agitators since the “competition of the market” would sift through the “fighting faiths” and eventually sort out winners from losers.

headline: Battling a Cartel in a Horrifying Quest to Find Her Daughter
abstract: Karen Rodriguez was kidnapped by Mexico’s Zeta cartel. Her mother would stop at nothing to find out exactly what happened to her.
lead_paragraph: It was 4 a.m. when Miriam Rodriguez’s phone rang and her daughter Azalea’s name popped up.

headline: My Running Club, My Everything
abstract: Group running has exploded in New York City. As friendships, marriages and even rivalries emerge, the benefits are proving as social as they are physical.
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday evening in early September, the Upper West Side Run Club met on the steps of the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. It was 6:30 p.m., and temperatures were hovering in the low 90s. But despite the extreme heat, over 25 people, ranging in age from teens to late 60s, showed up to run a four-mile loop around Central Park.

headline: Cash, Mules and Paid Protests: How a Fraudster Seized an Ethnic Enclave
abstract: The war in Ukraine is intensifying longstanding frictions in a region of Moldova called Gagauzia. A Moldovan convicted of plundering his country’s banking system sees an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Bundles of cash arriving on flights from Russia via Armenia provided an early sign of mischief in a tiny Eastern European enclave. Then came a wave of noisy street demonstrations featuring destitute pensioners paid to chant for the removal of their country’s pro-Western president.

headline: Clams Ruled This Town Until the Crabs Moved In
abstract: Goro, on the Adriatic Sea, is famous for its clams — essential for the beloved spaghetti alle vongole. But an infestation of crabs is threatening the town’s cash crop.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn in Goro, on the Adriatic Sea, Massimo Genari drove by the central roundabout, with its sculpture of two concrete clams in a net, and under a billboard of a mollusk donning a crimson royal crown. Wearing waders, he boarded his boat and motored to the lagoon with scores of other fishermen to rake the clam gardens that for decades have transformed this sleepy Italian village off the Po River Delta into a bivalve boomtown.

headline: Modern Masculinity Is Broken. She Knows How to Fix It.
abstract: “We need to work out what we want the future to look like for men in a way that women have already done,” says Caitlin Moran, the best-selling feminist author.
lead_paragraph: “We need to work out what we want the future to look like for men in a way that women have already done,” says Caitlin Moran, the best-selling feminist author.

headline: Republican Fashion Watch: Our Critic on 2024’s Hottest Trend
abstract: Ron DeSantis wears a “Ron DeSantis” shirt. Tim Scott sports a “Tim Scott” hat. Self-branding is all the rage for presidential candidates. To find out why, we asked Vanessa Friedman.
lead_paragraph: Some politicians need no introduction. The rest are running for the Republican nomination for president.

headline: In North Carolina, Republicans Seek More Control Over Elections
abstract: The G.O.P.-led legislature may seize control of state and local election boards from the Democratic governor, fueling a feud that could resonate in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before Gov. Roy Cooper, a North Carolina Democrat, began his first term in 2017, his rivals in the Republican-controlled legislature voted to strip the position of key powers, including the governor’s longstanding authority to appoint majorities to the state election board and local election boards in all 100 counties. After the state Supreme Court ruled that move illegal, the lawmakers put the idea on the ballot, but the state’s voters shot that down, too.

headline: Want to Spice Up a Marriage? Switch Bodies.
abstract: Isle McElroy’s second novel, “People Collide,” puts a pair of bored newlyweds in each other’s shoes.
lead_paragraph: Asked to choose flight or invisibility as a superpower — that old party game — how many novelists would choose flight, like captains of industry tend to do? Invisibility is, with little exception, the novelist’s superpower. Overhearing conversations. Entering bedrooms. Being, frankly, a little creepy.

headline: Why Are So Many Venezuelans Going to the United States?
abstract: Unable to build safe or stable lives in other parts of South America, many people are making the perilous journey to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans have arrived at the United States border in the last two years, part of a historic wave of migrants headed north amid growing global crises.

headline: Star Uyghur Scholar Who Vanished Was Sentenced to Life in China
abstract: Rahile Dawut, who recorded her people’s traditions, disappeared in 2017. New information indicates that she faces decades in prison.
lead_paragraph: She was a trailblazing professor and ethnographer from the Uyghur ethnic group in far-western China who documented the religious and cultural traditions of her people. She was at the height of a career that the Chinese government had once recognized with awards and research grants. But it was not enough to keep her safe.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Kidnapped Child Who Became a Poet’
abstract: At age 3, Shane McCrae was taken from his Black father by his white grandparents — a rupture he explores in a new memoir.
lead_paragraph: “The weird thing about growing up kidnapped,” Shane McCrae, the 47-year-old American poet, told me in his melodious, reedy voice one rainy afternoon in May, “is if it happens early enough, there’s a way in which you kind of don’t know.”

headline: This Alaska Mine Would Destroy the World’s Largest Salmon Fishery
abstract: The state’s governor has asked the Supreme Court to resurrect a widely opposed plan rejected by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: For decades, a Canadian company has sought to excavate an enormous open pit mine at the headwaters of the 40,000-square-mile Bristol Bay watershed in southwestern Alaska. Called the Pebble Mine, it would destroy the planet’s most productive salmon fishery and impoverish the communities the fishery sustains.

headline: Go Outside, Sink Your Feet Into the Dirt and Engage With the World
abstract: The natural world has stories to tell if you listen closely.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in Florida, surrounded by my extended family, but we can trace our lineage back to Texas when Texas was still Mexico. Our language, customs and even the names my ancestors called themselves have since largely been lost to colonization and forced assimilation. Yet our oral traditions, expressed through storytelling, poetry and jokes, persist.

headline: The Moral Theater of Social Justice Parenting
abstract: I can’t help feeling that as American culture has become more racially progressive, it’s also become more pathological about race.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t know what to make of the dolls. There were a half-dozen Black Barbies, Bratz and more arranged neatly on a windowsill. My wife and I were moving to coastal Maine, and as we walked through an open house, the toys in the child's room bothered me in a way that was not rational but visceral. I couldn’t escape the feeling that in this ritzy corner of New England, these were not only a child’s playthings but also props in her parents’ moral theater, an attempt to compensate for the homogeneous whiteness of their upwardly mobile suburb.

headline: The Unspeakably Sad Reminder of the ‘Other Paris’
abstract: The world is arranged to discreetly conceal the bleak side of life from us. And we are complicit.
lead_paragraph: Ava and I visited Paris twice on our vacation, at the beginning and again at the end of our trip. On those two occasions we saw two different cities, like the two city-states that occupy the same physical space in China Miéville’s novel “The City & the City,” whose respective inhabitants, living side by side, are forbidden to notice each other and must obtain passports to visit each other’s worlds.

headline: Being There
abstract: The principal duty of friendship is merely presence.
lead_paragraph: I want to begin this column by sharing with you one of the worst things I ever did. I was only 18 years old, but that was no excuse. Late one night I got a call from a close friend. “My dad’s on the way to the hospital,” he said. “It’s really bad.” His voice was shaking.

headline: Uncertainty ‘Is Killing Us’: Sikhs in India Are in Limbo Amid Canada Dispute
abstract: With Canada home to the largest Sikh population outside India, many Punjabis are caught in a diplomatic firestorm over the death of a separatist leader in British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Kulwant Singh, 45, shut his eyes tight and offered a prayer at the Sikh temple. Clutching a box of sweets and a shiny blue-and-white toy airplane, Mr. Singh and his teenage daughter, Navpreet Kaur, bowed outside the place of worship, Talhan Sahib in the North Indian state of Punjab.

headline: Amid Black Sea Threats, Ukraine Steps Up Use of New Shipping Route
abstract: The route has allowed Kyiv to revive exports of grain and other goods across the Black Sea despite Russia’s wartime threats to commercial shipping.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has stepped up its use of a new shipping route that has allowed it to begin reviving grain exports to circumvent a de facto Russian blockade of its Black Sea ports.

headline: The Rise of Run Clubs
abstract: In Berlin, some marathon runners came for the party.
lead_paragraph: The marathon runners were wearing neon and sipping beers.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 25, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Just Like Mom Used to Make
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s new recipe for goulash is a great use of old spices (hear us out).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Lidey Heuck gave us a new recipe for goulash (above) that’s an Americanized take on the great Hungarian stew, with paprika-scented ground beef, bell peppers, diced tomatoes, macaroni and a healthy sprinkle of Cheddar stirred in at the end.

headline: Forests: Friend, Not Foe, in Climate Change
abstract: Conservation groups react to a guest essay about the negative impact of forests. Also: Challenging antisemitism; Republicans and migrants; shoes-off homes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Usher to Headline Super Bowl Halftime Show
abstract: “It’s an honor of a lifetime to finally check a Super Bowl performance off my bucket list,” the eight-time Grammy winner said.
lead_paragraph: Usher Raymond, the eight-time Grammy-winning singer known as Usher, will headline the halftime show of Super Bowl LVIII in Las Vegas, the National Football League, Roc Nation and Apple Music announced on Sunday. It comes in the second year of the league’s multiyear deal with Apple Music and will be Usher’s first time starring in the show.

headline: Dana Perino of Fox News Is About to Face Her Biggest Test as a Journalist
abstract: The former press secretary in the Bush White House will moderate the next Republican debate. She’s managed to rise at Fox without being a Trump supplicant.
lead_paragraph: Dana Perino can punch and parry with the best of them. But she could be better at ducking.

headline: White House Steps Up Warnings of Shutdown Impact as Deadline Nears
abstract: President Biden and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg made public calls for Republicans, who remain at an impasse over funding the government, to resolve their differences before next Sunday.
lead_paragraph: With a potential government shutdown now less than a week away, President Biden and other administration officials this weekend intensified their warnings of the consequences of closing government agencies as they pressed congressional Republicans to find a way out of their spending stalemate.

headline: Refugees Flee to Armenia as Breakaway Enclave Comes Under Azerbaijan’s Control
abstract: More than 1,000 people crossed the border from the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh on Sunday, days after a military offensive returned the ethnic Armenian enclave to Azerbaijan’s control.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 ethnic Armenians fleeing the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh crossed the border into Armenia on Sunday, days after a military offensive brought the enclave firmly back under Azerbaijan’s control.

headline: As Trump Prosecutions Move Forward, Threats and Concerns Increase
abstract: As criminal cases proceed against the former president, heated rhetoric and anger among his supporters have the authorities worried about the risk of political dissent becoming deadly.
lead_paragraph: At the federal courthouse in Washington, a woman called the chambers of the judge assigned to the election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and said that if Mr. Trump were not re-elected next year, “we are coming to kill you.”

headline: Canadian Labor Union Votes to Ratify Contract With Ford
abstract: The deal with Unifor was a relief for the Detroit automaker, whose U.S. union has begun a limited strike over better pay and benefits.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian labor union Unifor said on Sunday that its members had voted to ratify a new contract with Ford Motor, a relief for the Detroit automaker, which is locked in a separate battle with its U.S. union over demands for better pay and benefits.

headline: Black High School Student Suspended Over His Hair Length Sues Texas Leaders
abstract: Darryl George and his mother filed a federal lawsuit after the teenager was suspended because his hairstyle violated a school district dress code.
lead_paragraph: A Black high school student in Texas who was suspended because of the way he wears his hair, along with his mother, filed a federal civil rights lawsuit on Saturday against the state’s governor and attorney general.

headline: Newsom Vetoes Bill on Parental Support of Child’s Gender Identity in Custody Cases
abstract: The bill would have instructed judges in custody battles to weigh a parent’s support for a child’s gender identity. The governor’s veto breaks from his usual stance on transgender rights.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed a bill on Friday that would instruct judges presiding over custody battles in the state to take into consideration a parent’s support for a child’s gender identity when making custody and visitation decisions.

headline: ‘Doppelganger’ Review: A Soldier Confronts His Mortality
abstract: At the Park Avenue Armory, an imaginative and viscerally shocking staging of Schubert songs from the director Claus Guth and the tenor Jonas Kaufmann.
lead_paragraph: In the classical tradition, a song often evokes intimacy and solitude: a poet baring vulnerability, a composer painting a miniature. That sense of seclusion extends to the performance as well: a singer and pianist alone onstage, a listener absorbing the work in an intimate recital hall or immersed, alone, with headphones.

headline: Tropical Storm Philippe Continues to Crawl Over Atlantic
abstract: The National Hurricane Center said that the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico should monitor the progress of Philippe as another storm, Rina, formed east of it.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Philippe, which formed last week, was crawling southwestward on Saturday as it continued to interact with Tropical Storm Rina, which formed to its east.

headline: France to Withdraw Troops From Niger After Military Coup
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron said he had also recalled the country’s ambassador, after weeks of escalating tensions with Niger’s new military leaders.
lead_paragraph: France will withdraw nearly 1,500 troops from the West African nation of Niger by the end of the year, President Emmanuel Macron said on Sunday, a decision that could upend the West’s security footprint in the region, including the future of 1,100 American forces based in Niger.

headline: ‘A disguised welcome …’ Review: Finding Home
abstract: Wanjiru Kamuyu’s solo performance at the Chocolate Factory Theater in Queens isn’t a straightforward immigration story.
lead_paragraph: At 16, Wanjiru Kamuyu, who was born in Kenya to a Kenyan father and an African American mother, moved with her mother to the United States.

headline: Monday Briefing: How China Is Walling Off the Sea
abstract: Plus pursuing K-pop stardom while being out and proud.
lead_paragraph: This is what it looks like when a Chinese naval vessel bears down on your boat, as experienced firsthand by our reporters, who were on board a Philippine-flagged fishing vessel. They were reporting on how Beijing was imposing its territorial ambitions on the South China Sea.

headline: A Kinetic Cloud of Humanity for Moynihan Train Hall
abstract: Joshua Frankel, an artist whose grandfather worked at the James Farley Post Office, has deep roots at the site of his new video project for Art at Amtrak.
lead_paragraph: A bouncy strut, a dart-and-weave, a dawdle with a dog. A stroller, a grocery cart, a wheelchair. A burqa, a beanie, a bowler.

headline: ‘Dracula, a Comedy of Terrors’ Review: An Equal-Opportunity Seducer
abstract: A gender-bending play at New World Stages filters well-known characters through influences like “The Rocky Horror Show” and “Young Frankenstein.”
lead_paragraph: You don’t need to have been to Transylvania to know that one way to kill vampires is with a stake through the heart. In “Dracula, a Comedy of Terrors,” a gender-bending play at New World Stages, Dr. Van Helsing calls for a “shtick” to slay her greatest foe. Or at least that’s what “stake” sounds like after it’s been mauled by Arnie Burton’s German-accented, female Van Helsing.

headline: Sound Systems
abstract: Lynn Lempel tells us what it’s all about.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: A Small German City Staves Off a Threat From the Far Right
abstract: Voters on Sunday rejected the candidate for the hard-line Alternative for Germany Party, which is rattling German national politics, in the race for mayor in the city of Nordhausen.
lead_paragraph: With a colorless and reputedly prickly small-city mayor being challenged by a far-right candidate known for his charisma and business success, many Germans feared that the hard-line Alternative for Germany party was about to win its first City Hall.

headline: F.B.I. Investigating Charges of Abuse by Baton Rouge Police in ‘Brave Cave’
abstract: Lawsuits filed in federal court said officers detained, abused and humiliated detainees in an unmarked “torture warehouse.”
lead_paragraph: A grandmother detained by the Baton Rouge police for mixing two different prescription pills in the same container said officers interrogated and humiliated her in an unmarked “torture warehouse” known as the Brave Cave, according to a lawsuit filed last week.

headline: Polls Show Low Approval Ratings for Biden, and Trump Coasting in Primary
abstract: Surveys from NBC News and The Washington Post/ABC News pointed to a general election between two unpopular candidates.
lead_paragraph: Two polls of the 2024 presidential race released on Sunday showed former President Donald J. Trump cruising through the Republican primary — and a general election between two unpopular candidates if, as seems likely, the nominees are Mr. Trump and President Biden.

headline: Where does the actors’ strike stand?
abstract: The writers’ agreement could expedite negotiations, as some of SAG-AFTRA’s concerns are similar to ones raised by the Writers Guild.
lead_paragraph: The resolution of the writers’ strike will not restore Hollywood to normal, as the union representing more than 150,000 actors, SAG-AFTRA, is striking separately and has demands that exceed those of the Writers Guild. No talks between the actors’ union and the studios are currently scheduled.

headline: 6 on the Way to a Birthday Party Are Killed After a Train Hits an S.U.V.
abstract: Five of the dead were identified as a couple and their children. They were on their way to a celebration before dying in a violent collision in Plant City, Fla., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Five members of a family and a friend who were on their way to a birthday party were killed after the S.U.V. in which they were traveling was struck by a train Saturday evening at a quiet railroad crossing in Plant City, Fla., the local authorities said.

headline: The agreement could put talk shows back on the air.
abstract: Late-night and daytime talk shows could return after the resolution of the writers’ strike, potentially bringing relief to one corner of the industry.
lead_paragraph: As the actors’ strike continues on, most television shows and movies will not be able to resume without them. But late-night and daytime talk shows could return after the resolution of the writers’ strike, potentially bringing relief to one corner of the industry.

headline: An Ancient Whale Named for King Tut, but Moby-Dinky in Size
abstract: Paleontologists in Egypt announced the discovery of Tutcetus rayanensis, an eight-foot-long leviathan that lived 41 million years ago.
lead_paragraph: In 1842, a vast, nearly intact skeleton was unearthed on a plantation in Alabama; it was soon identified as a member of Basilosaurus, a recently named genus of prehistoric sea serpent. But when some of its enormous bones were shipped to England, Richard Owen, an anatomist, noted that its molars had two roots, not one, a dental morphology unknown in any reptile. He determined that the fossil was actually a marine mammal: a primitive whale. Herman Melville name-drops the behemoth — Mr. Owen called it Zeuglodon — in Chapter 104 of “Moby-Dick,” and Mr. Owen, in a paper that he read to the London Geological Society, pronounced it “one of the most extraordinary creatures which the mutations of the globe have blotted out of existence.”

headline: Greece, Battered a Decade Ago, Is Booming
abstract: It is one of Europe’s fastest-growing economies, and while investors and tourists are flocking to the country, memories of austerity measures are still fresh for Greeks.
lead_paragraph: Paris Skouros pointed toward the sky outside his office in Athens on a recent weekday. In the past six months, four high-rises had sprung up, built by Greek and international builders to be sold for use as tourist rentals, foreign real estate investments and company offices. Farther afield, a fresh crop of new buildings dotted the horizon.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Europe’s struggle to supply Ukraine
lead_paragraph: European Union states agreed in March to a $2.1 billion plan that would deliver a million rounds of 155-millimeter ammunition to Ukraine within a year. Now, at a critical moment in the war and with Ukraine running short of artillery shells to drive its counteroffensive, experts say Europe may not be able to ramp up production fast enough to achieve the million-shell goal.

headline: Why an Ex-Sex Crimes Prosecutor Is Fighting Netflix
abstract: Linda Fairstein argues that the series “When They See Us” about the Central Park Five case defamed her.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at a ruling in a defamation lawsuit over a 2019 Netflix series about the Central Park Five case. We’ll also get details on the indictment against Senator Robert Menendez and his wife.

headline: Matteo Messina Denaro, Long-Sought Italian Mafia Boss, Dies at 61
abstract: A high-ranking member of the Cosa Nostra, he was arrested in January after decades on the run. He was found through medical records related to his cancer treatment.
lead_paragraph: Matteo Messina Denaro, a convicted killer and high-ranking mobster with the Sicilian Cosa Nostra who had eluded capture for three decades, died on Monday in a hospital in the central Italian city of L’Aquila, where he had been serving time in a maximum-security prison. He was 61.

headline: Quotation of the Day:Missing Uyghur ScholarIs Jailed for Life in China
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Those perpetrating this injustice are fully aware of the degree of the injustice. Why else would this need to be kept secret?”

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 25, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Egypt Is Exhuming the Dead and Evicting the Living
abstract: A historic area of Cairo is being razed to make way for President el-Sisi’s Pharaonic fantasies.
lead_paragraph: My mother, who died suddenly when I was a teenager, is buried alongside her ancestors in a historic mausoleum in the area of Cairo known as the City of the Dead. It’s the oldest continuously used Muslim cemetery in the world, and its history traces back to the seventh century. My ancestors chose this burial place in order to be near Imam al-Shafi’i, a ninth-century holy man who rests in a magnificent shrine there. My family has five mausoleums in the vicinity; the oldest is from the 1790s. From the outside they resemble the courtyarded houses of medieval Cairo. Inside there are gardens, carved marble cenotaphs and ornately decorated rooms, hung with dusty chandeliers, where grievers used to hold all-night vigils on holidays and death anniversaries.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Golden Bachelor’ and ‘The Irrational’
abstract: A spinoff of the popular dating show joins the ABC franchise. And NBC premieres a new crime procedural show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 25-Oct. 1. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: On Day 146, Screenwriters Reach Deal With Studios to End Their Strike
abstract: The Writers Guild of America got most of what it wanted. With actors still on picket lines, however, much of Hollywood will remain shut down.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s bitter, monthslong labor dispute has taken a big first step toward a resolution.

abstract: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word littoral has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 2 in “A California Beach Town Is Desperate to Save Its Vanishing Sand” by Jill Cowan:

headline: Firefighters Respond to Strike on Odesa Hotel
abstract: The hotel, which stood as a landmark in the Port of Odesa, was unoccupied, according to regional officials.
lead_paragraph: The hotel, which stood as a landmark in the Port of Odesa, was unoccupied, according to regional officials.

headline: How the G.O.P. Candidates Get Debate-Ready
abstract: Tennis practice. Pump-up music. Prayer. Republican candidates share their pre-debate rituals.
lead_paragraph: Tennis practice. Pump-up music. Prayer. Republican candidates share their pre-debate rituals.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Editor’s note: Be sure to check out Part 2 of Getting to Genius, a series where two Games editors take you through the best way to get better at Spelling Bee.

headline: ‘Gold’: A Word Rarely Mentioned in Menendez’s Senate Disclosure Forms
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez is accused of accepting bribes in an indictment that refers to “gold” 26 times and says that 13 gold bars were found in his home.
lead_paragraph: The word “gold” appears 26 times in the federal indictment unsealed Friday against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey along with his wife, Nadine, and three businessmen.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: 2 Looming Rulings Could Shape Trump’s Fraud Trial in New York
abstract: Donald J. Trump has adopted a long-shot legal strategy to try to delay his upcoming civil trial and severely limit the case against him.
lead_paragraph: After four years of investigating and litigating, Letitia James was finally due for her day in court against Donald J. Trump.

headline: What Is a Gallery?
abstract: T’s 2023 Art issue looks at a New York subculture that has been a fixture of the city’s history — and highly influential on its development over the last century.
lead_paragraph: Commercial galleries are an old business, and a unique one within the New York City economy, something between a storefront and a salon, the anchor of both a largely unregulated marketplace and of creative expression itself. The earliest examples of galleries in New York, from the first half of the 19th century, predate every major museum and auction house in the metropolitan area, not to mention Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Empire State Building and Grand Central Terminal. This would seem to suggest there is something indelible about galleries in the landscape of this city and, by extension, any truly global city that values culture. That New York has the largest network of galleries in the world is a fact that many observers of the art business simply take for granted: Why does New York have so many galleries? Because it’s the center of the art world. Why is New York the center of the art world? Because it has so many galleries.

headline: Trump vs. Biden Would Be a Battle of Two Words
abstract: If it’s a rematch between the incumbent and the former president, their dueling visions for America come down to a specific lexicon.
lead_paragraph: Politicians’ language can tell you a lot about the way they think, sometimes unintentionally.

headline: In Her Fiction, Ayana Mathis Refuses to Ignore Black History
abstract: Her second novel, “The Unsettled,” follows three generations in a family divided between the North and the South in 1980s America.
lead_paragraph: As a novelist and a student of history, I’m interested in the question of whether Black novelists must acknowledge history in our work, or if it is possible, in the name of artistic freedom, to truly set it aside. I, for one, submit that Black history will always hover over American literature, whether or not the author intends it to. As Toni Morrison wrote in 1992, the Black American population “preceded every American writer of renown and was, I have come to believe, one of the most furtively radical impinging forces on the country’s literature.”
